NGL, this is beautiful game Sims 4 is my escape from real life, however having played the previous iterations of Sims, this current version pales in comparison on so many levels. Playing with it takes a little out of me each time, its like eating food without any seasoning. It fills you up, but its bland and you don't want more of it when you are full. So I turn it off and leave it for months at a time. 

But I always come back to it because I need Sims in my life. Frankly, if there is a more authentic experience, more like the older versions, namely sims 1 and sims 2, I'd drop this game immediately. But for the moment there is none. So here I am.

Been playing Sims for 23 years so obviously I love the game. Time melts away in building homes, growing gardens, learning new skills, bothering the neighbors... you name it.  Is it perfect? Of course not, it's crazy expensive if you ever want to delve beyond the base game. Even with only purchasing on sale dates, it adds up if you want it all. It was nice they made the base game free but it was way too late for me. They're constantly adding new stuff! I don't always care for it but it's great that there is effort to cater to such a wide variety of interests. Keep in mind, for some reason you can ride a bike but you can't drive a car... hopefully they bring that back again one day. And if you're willing to give it a go, the amount of user made custom content is immeasurable. You have to enjoy a slower paced, low action game. Even at high speed, it's not Call of Duty, it's Sims, just relax and enjoy shaping the lives of strangers in pretty much any way you can image.

As of writing this review there are;

Fifteen 'different' $40.00 expansion packs. - Totaling around $520.00
Twelve 'game packs' for $20.00 each. - Totaling around $240.00
TWENTY 'stuff packs' all $10.00 each. - Totaling around $200.00
Nearly THIRTY 'kits' all $5.00 each. - Totaling around $95.00
... and a digital 'upgrade' pack for $10.00 that adds items and clothes- as well as the soundtrack.

All this comes down to over $1000.00 - prices based on an article by PCGamesN.

 [b]Some people argue this adds a lot of variety to the series. In reality it adds;[/b]

• Instability to your save file.
• Slow in-game processing power.
• TONS of unchecked glitches and bugs.
• Broken interactions between your Sims or pets.
• Complete corruption of your 'towns'.
• A sad, empty wallet.

The funny part is just how many features this game has subtracted from previous games in the series- including various modes of transportation, the ability to create and interact with your actual towns instead of just giving you two-dimensional plots to work with, the ability to control your pets, and countless other important quality of life features the other games had.

On top of this you will receive a mostly broken launcher they released that was not even originally necessary for playing the game. Because of this 'thing' you will run into the inability to actually play the game for several days with the release of each new 'update'. And these updates are FREQUENT because instead of streamlining their ideas- they pump out new kits and 'collaborations' that nobody actually asked for and proceed to milk the Sims community completely dry like a Cow Plant.

There are some VERY die-hard fans who defend every action of this franchise. Needless to say; they're totally misguided. EA is not a good company- everyone knows that- but in the Sims' case they're not even good game designers. There are countless issues that could be solved with simpler, smarter fixes that they continue to ignore in lieu of patches that break the game for days at a time. This is not a modding exclusive problem either- it goes down for EVERYONE.

I should mention the Sims 4 developers enjoy pandering to certain audiences- and do it in a blatantly obvious manner. Collaborations with the Sims 4 are usually very shallow or frivolous to drum up the idea that they are 'champions of the people' in cultural representation. The truth is they are anything but that- they just want your money at the end of the day. The Sims franchise isn't about sending a message to the masses- it's just a video game series people enjoy winding down with at the end of the day. Everyone wants representation in some form or another- a completely fair thing to ask for- but The Sims 4 does it in such an insincere and corporate fashion that it turns my stomach. Don't fall for their false sense of equality- there are better places to look for it than an overrated and overpriced video game series.

[b]TLDR;[/b] You should avoid buying this game. If you're a die-hard Sims fan and you already own it; I advise you to be smart with your money and buy packs VERY selectively. Some will break your game, others will add nothing of real value to it. Always check user reviews to find out the PROS and CONS of each pack you want to purchase. You should typically only buy these packs or expansions on SALE; otherwise you will be wasting your money on a game you may end up playing for about a week sporadically throughout the year.

A fun and enjoyable life simulator without being overly mature or overly cartoon-ish.

Since the base game is free now it doesn't hurt to give it a shot to see if you like it. You'll probably need a pack or two like Seasons and Growing Together to make it a more enjoyable game since those are essentially base game 2.0. I don't recommend buying any DLC at full price though, wait for a sale which they do often. Definitely watch video reviews about the packs from a reviewer who is NOT an EA Game Changer like LGR or SatchOnSims because some packs sound good on paper but have poor execution. If you're only playing it for building you can just download mods for furniture, wallpapers etc instead of buying packs. That being said, if you hate the base game then no amount of DLC will make this a good game for you. They don't change the gameplay enough for that.

Overall this is still a cash-grabby DLC simulator and a buggy game (you'll probably need mods to fix the annoyances since Maxis is allergic to fixing broken packs. Seriously, Dine Out is still broken but there is a mod that completely overhauls it) but my opinion of it has sort of improved recently. Still not as great as The Sims 2 and 3 as this game lacks the humor, ambition and attention to detail as the previous games, but as someone who has burned herself out on those games by playing them too much this is the next best thing on the market at the moment.

The Sims 4: Build, Play, Live, Repeat

First off, let's talk about build mode. Now, don't get me wrong, I could spend hours tinkering with floor plans and picking out the perfect wallpaper. But can we please talk about those swatches? Like, seriously EA, we need more neutral and cohesive options up in here. Sometimes I feel like I'm trying to match my sims' living room to a unicorn's rainbow vomit. But hey, despite the struggle, I find myself sucked into the Sims universe for hours on end. It's like a black hole of creativity and procrastination.

And let's address the elephant in the room – the never-ending parade of DLCs. Look, I get it, EA needs to make that coin, but do they have to make it rain expansions like it's confetti at Coachella? It's like, chill out with the pricey packs, fam. But hey, it's not like The Sims 4 is the first game to pull this stunt. We've seen it before, and we'll probably see it again.

But you know what? Despite the occasional frustration and wallet-emptying moments, I keep coming back for more. There's just something magical about watching my sims' lives unfold, even if I have to restart my build for the umpteenth time because suddenly everything looks wrong. The Sims 4 has come a long way and even though it's not perfect, it's still hella addictive.

So, if you're like me, a sucker for pixelated perfection and virtual escapism, give The Sims 4 a whirl. Just be prepared to lose track of time and maybe a few dollars along the way. But hey, isn't that what gaming is all about?

[b] 4 Mar 2023: [/b]  w/ latest updates and EA Software being forced on us, Origin is gone :( And they now require us to use their EA Software. With this in mind, I've commented in a thread and want to re-post what I posted there concerning trying to launch the game with steam and how it reacts to EA Software and launching the game itself. 


UPDATE: Seems if you clear cache and just close down both steam and ea, then reboot your PC that you can then launch it from steam but I recommend you open them both before you launch via steam. I tried from desktop and that did not launch EA Software properly. IDK if adding EA Software to Steam's Programs would help but I worry it'll affect play time documented, which is cool to see.

Update 2: I tried again today. I do my typical routine of steam stuff. I then go to launch the game and so it begins. I've tried verify integrity. I've tried clearing cache on both EA Software & Steam Cache. Both cause you to have to log in again. Even then I get that error, 500 and I'll know it'll be an issue before I even get to see my game page in EA Software because EA Software will launch with a yellow banner stating something is off. If the EA Software launches and does NOT have that yellow banner, it seems to launch each time. Once I get the game going I do not go messing with it so these tests are some time in between. I hope that helps some of you until it's fixed. I also sent an error report in EA Software (Desktop software aka EA App/Program) for PC.

Restarting pc after clearing cache? IDK but that's a lot of steps. Restarting does and is part of what makes it work. The lack of yellow banner is also a part of what makes it work. Yellow banner means my game information will not be accessible because of some mysterious situation. O.o

31 Jan 2023: Newest BASE GAME update includes surgical marks for sex changes and medical clothing for gender changes. The one thing I did notice is patches that can be worn on the skin. That could be for diabetics or heart patients? I still wish it was a free DLC, then you could get more medical supplies, braces, etc. I think they added this one more for political reasons, to make a point. I prefer a free DLC of medical, or a low fee. I'd buy it as a medical care kit, if it were that. (Note: there's also no prosthetic limbs & you'll have to pay for the dentures in a cup) I think it was just a way to get their way, tbh. This is my personal opinion.

Just head over to Origin if you own Origin and you'll see your previous hours there, as well as updated hours if you have the steam version. :) Origin should have all hours displayed though Steam only picks up when you buy STEAM base game. Origin also shows which packs you own (it shows if it's a STEAM purchase as well) so check Origin when you want to know what packs you don't have. Steam doesn't seem to be able to track that. Then go to STEAM store and ignore what you already own so you don't buy it again.

Introduction:
"The Sims 4" offers players a vibrant and immersive simulation experience where creativity knows no bounds. From designing dream homes to shaping the lives of virtual characters, this game invites players into a world of endless possibilities.

Graphics and Design:
Visually, "The Sims 4" is stunning. The colorful and detailed graphics bring the world to life, whether you're exploring bustling neighborhoods or customizing your Sims' appearances. The intuitive design makes navigating menus and building structures a breeze, even for newcomers to the series.

Gameplay and Features:
The core gameplay of "The Sims 4" revolves around managing the lives of virtual characters known as Sims. Players can create unique Sims with distinct personalities, aspirations, and appearances, allowing for endless customization. The game offers a plethora of activities for Sims to engage in, from pursuing careers and hobbies to forming relationships and starting families. With the addition of expansion packs, players can further enrich their gameplay experience with new content such as pets, seasons, and supernatural beings.

Immersion and Replayability:
One of the standout features of "The Sims 4" is its immersive nature. Players can become deeply invested in the lives of their Sims, forming emotional connections as they guide them through various milestones and challenges. The game's replayability is virtually limitless, thanks to its open-ended nature and the constant stream of updates and expansion packs that introduce fresh content and gameplay mechanics.

Community and Mods:
"The Sims 4" boasts a vibrant and passionate community of players who share creations, stories, and mods. The availability of user-generated content adds another layer of depth to the game, allowing players to further personalize their experience and explore new possibilities.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, "The Sims 4" is a captivating and immersive simulation game that offers endless opportunities for creativity and storytelling. With its stunning graphics, rich gameplay features, and thriving community, it continues to delight players of all ages. Whether you're a seasoned Sims veteran or new to the series, "The Sims 4" is sure to provide hours of entertainment and inspiration.

I really love the Sims 4 because the room for creativity are endless. I enjoy thinking up a backstory and developing a Sim to fit seamlessly into my plot. I have been playing for 2 years and I still have packs and ideas that I have yet to use. EA made a great decision when they welcomed Mods into the game. Mods add even more to a game that is basically endless. I found myself on day being extremely upset because I lost me beloved Grandmother. It got me thinking about heaven and what my heaven would look like. So, then I imagined what my Grandmothers version of heaven would be and I decided to build it. I went to The Sims Resource and downloaded some angel wings and a halo. My Gran always dreamed about building a log home up in Wisconsin, but she as unable to do so. So I went to CAS and made my Gran into a SIM and then I sent her through the tree to Sylvan Glade. I build her version of heaven and it turned out so beautiful that I shared it with the rest of my family and we all found it to be incredibly cathartic and comforting. Sims 4 helped me and my family heal from the loss of my Grandmother and that's just 1 thing that Sims 4 is capable of.  Thank you for making such an important game!

So I got to thinking more about this and the game is pretty gross. If you approach it from a purely gaming perspective, unless you are farming reward points and popping potions of youth, your first sim or sims are going to die. And farming "people" with preferred stats and traits in colony sims is not an uncommon or particularly varied concept. But in The Sims it feels very different. Maybe that's because the people are modeled so much towards human beings or maybe its by design. All I know is that in my game I married a hot criminal mastermind that flew off the handle randomly but was a decent companion. Too real at this point but I'll continue. Farming potions for both was taking all my time so she unfortunately had to go but I keep her urn next to the tv so all good. Now the task ahead was to find an heir to my castle and fortune. And by that I mean moderately sized middle class home and a couple hundred grand. It was tedious at first and involved a LOT of... interactions. And soon I found the only one traited to raising a kid was not into men, at all. This is where it got REALLY strange. Because from a gaming perspective the next logical course of action is to look for the next source of "people" to create new sims with. I was scrolling through the streets on full speed, waiting to see new faces. It got to the point where I was recognizing when teens turned to young adults so I could peg them once and get their profile details to make things quicker and that's when it hit me. The Sims is not a people simulator, its a grooming simulator.

The TS4 base game is free. You may look at it and figure that for a free game, surely it can't be that bad. But once you start playing, you will immediately begin to notice the cracks. Unlike previous Sims games, TS4 lacks depth and engaging gameplay, making the base game feel like an unfinished demo. Travelling anywhere requires loading screens, relationships are shallow, and the sim AI is frustrating and annoying. There is so little to do in this game. And naturally, you are going to begin to look at the packs, which the launcher advertises whenever you open the game.
Buying packs is expensive. There are so many that it can be overwhelming to pick, especially since many of them seem like they add essential features that you need. And worst of all, purchasing these packs will not fix your game. It will actually make it worse. For every tiny bit of gameplay you will also have to put up with more annoyances, longer loading screens, and more bugs. And there will be many bugs. Some of them are bad enough to corrupt save files and crash the game. But because packs are so expensive, you try to convince yourself that it isn't so bad. You may even spend more money, and feel more indebted to this game. How could these packs be so expensive and so shallow, so broken? You may think it is your fault, that you are missing something, that you made the wrong purchases. And so it looks like the only escape from the hole is to dig deeper.
EA is a company that does not care about this game. TS4 has so many game breaking bugs, and packs that have been broken since their release years ago. They have a long history of ignoring player complaints, refusing refunds, and continuing to push new content no matter the backlash. They have no accountability, because this game is too big for a few players to hold them responsible. Every trailer hypes up every new pack as a must buy, and after release EA goes radio silent until the next new pack, leaving players to struggle with their newly broken game, because each patch breaks things further.
TS4 is 10 years old. It is not going to get any better. If you are in the market for a life simulation game, then you should look at any of the recent newer entries to the genre. If you download the base game, even though it is free, it will tempt you to buy these very well advertised packs that will break your game. The game engine was terrible to begin with, and piling more content on a broken foundation only makes things worse.
There are two positives to this game: first, there is a very engaging build mode, and it's quite fun to design different houses in this game. There are still bugs, but they're minimal if you don't have a lot of packs, and you can take some beautiful designs and share them on the public gallery for others to download. Second, TS4 has a huge dedicated modding community, so if you're playing on PC and can mod your game then you can get so much engaging and interesting content for free thanks to the work of these talented players. I don't think they're enough to make this a good game, but you may feel differently.
If you already own the game and are thinking of buying a pack, three rules to follow: 1) look up several gameplay videos. Make sure they're complete, with no cuts to hide bugs or annoyances. There's a million different Sims channels on Youtube, so do your research. 2) Never buy a pack full price. There are enough sales that you can wait until it's at least half off. 3) NEVER preorder a pack. They will try to entice you with exclusive content, but it is not worth it. New packs are always broken and may not get fixed for months, if at all.
But if you don't own this game, don't get it. The sunk cost fallacy is the main reason for this game's success, and EA have very good advertisements and a huge online community to encourage you to spend a little more. Maybe this time the game will be worth it. Maybe this time they'll be different. But after 10 years of consistency, maybe its time to accept that there never was a good game here, and it's time to let go.

Bought this game when it was $59.99 and wasn't free to play; along with a couple DLC's. Opened up the game recently and found that the that 2 of the 3 that I bought are now free and so is the game itself. I was compensated $0.00. I'm not in the best position financially, but the eighty something dollars doesn't even matter. The financial cataclysm that EA ensued on so many folks, who bought a majority of their ridiculously priced DLC, is unfathomable. I read another review that stated someone spent around a thousand dollars to get the game and all available DLC. How much do you want to bet they saw none of their money be refunded and that they'd be taken to court if they tried to claim compensation or take legal action against EA? They'd probably somehow legalese their way into flipping it on the poor guy and sue him for defamation with their squad of elite lawyers. I will never support EA again for the rest of my life. These are horrible people who bend laws and take advantage of their customers with their untouchable financial & social status. And it's our fault they have this position in the world.

EA itself doesn't put quite as much juice in the packs as they should, but getting the packs is still made worth it by the incredible modding community, really bringing the most in each pack. The game is very lackluster without DLC (which is why it's free) and honestly quite boring, but if that's all you can afford at this time, then there are plenty of mods that are easy to apply that make the base game significantly more enjoyable. If anyone has any awesome mod recommendations, please let me know. Sims 4 is genuinely the most mold-able game I've ever played and you can really make whatever experience you want. Another big thanks to the mod community (LOVE the vampire interaction mods)

[h1] A Great Way To Escape Real Life! [/h1] 
The Sims 4 is a 2014 social simulation game developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts. It is the fourth major title in The Sims series, and is the sequel to The Sims 3 (2009). The Sims 4 focuses on its improved character creation and house building tools, as well as deeper in-game simulation with the new emotion and personality systems for Sims.many free updates have been released throughout the game's lifespan that include major features and additions to the game, such as the addition of swimming pools, character customization options, and terrain tools.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]The graphics are the best in the franchise! I really enjoy the graphics for the SIms 4. The lighting is pretty nice and everything looks pretty sharp and has an ageless art style in my opinion. The animations are good as well which is a plus (especially the facial animations). The UI is pretty good too, but can get kinda messy to me at times. I would highly recommend a reshade as well, because this makes all the color's and artstyle truly pop and looks absolutely stunning![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Gameplay has so many elements to talk about. You can have jobs, create a social media platform, go on dates, basically anything you could do in real life, well mostly. The building in this game is the best I have seen in a game. You can literally make any place you want. Honestly I have most of my hours in the building section of this game, that’s how good it is. You can build basically anything you want and it feels so good too. I barely have any issues with the building tools in this game. It’s hard to talk about since you have so much in the gameplay section it would be too long to read. I will talk about some negatives though. The worlds are small and you have to go through a loading screen each time you go to a new area or location which can take you out of the immersion at times. This game has a TON of DLC’s. It’s almost criminal how many there are. The worst part is that some of these DLC’s should have been in the game![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Story? You are the story! You can make any story you want in this game. You can have a long family history if you play long enough in your playthrough. You can have a family and give them careers, traits, different attitudes, basically anything. The story is up to your imagination and that's the beauty about the sims. It’s basically a life simulation if that makes any sense. The freedom is high and do what you want as you are one of many sims in this beautiful world of freedom.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]The amount of playtime this game has is absolutely insane. Just from building alone, I have 800+ Hours! You can do almost anything in this game and the hours show. If you want a game to pass time on, here you go![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound is pretty good. The music is pretty chill and your Sims speak a language we will never understand. You will have audio cues from your sims that represent emotion, and you can also edit your characters voice which is pretty cool. The sound department is great and I have no issues. There is probably too much to talk about in this section so i’ll just keep it short.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]You will have some bugs. The pathing is kinda meh at times and your sims will do some weird things that they are not supposed to do. Like for example they go in a pool when they can’t swim and they drown, that’s annoying! Their personality can be kinda odd like not following what their traits are but that doesn’t happen all the time. The building mechanics are good but placing things accurately is a no no unless you use console commands.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The Sims 4 runs pretty well for me. If you have a lot of detail on the map or sims it can get a little laggy but that’s to be expected. Besides that issue it runs pretty good in my opinion and the lag was never distracting if it ever came up.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]A ton of freedom
[*]Still being updated
[*]Amazing story telling
[*]Incredible mod support
[*]Can truly get immersed
[*]Many personality traits
[*]Good character customization
[*]Super chill/relaxing experience
[*]Able to share builds and characters
[*]You can be really creative on your builds with little to no limitations
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Requires EA app
[*]Too many DLC’s
[*]Way too expensive
[*]Not many worlds in Vanilla game
[*]Some content should have been in vanilla game
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]7/10
Give this game a try since this is free. The DLC's are really expensive and I only recommend getting them all if you are gonna put a ton of time into this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]This is my first Sims game and I absolutely love it. The building is nearly perfect and you can have your own family. Create many families and scenarios that can truly get you immersed. The Sims 4 is perfect for people who are looking for a relaxing, stress fee, and immersive/sandbox setting. If you love sandbox games, creating/sharing builds, and having an immersive role-playing experience this is a must buy![/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

I was fourteen going on fifteen when the original “The Sims” was released back in 2000, and have spent countless hours over the past twenty-four years playing the many incarnations of the game, including The Sims, The Sims (Console), The Sims Online, The Sims 2, The Sims 2 (PSP), The Sims 2 (Mobile), The Sims 3, The Sims 3 (Wii), The Sims Social, and now The Sims 4.  
That said, I’m really satisfied with this version of the game. It feels like a mixture of the three previous (main) titles. It works because it’s essentially a reboot—taking place in an “alternate universe” inhabited by some familiar faces.
Does the game have bugs? Sure, but what game doesn’t—especially nowadays, where there’s a constant demand for new content, which gets prioritized over fixing existing issues. 
My primary grievance with the game is the lack of thought-out backgrounds for existing characters. If you’re lucky, you get a short blurb with a brief description of the family dynamic. Otherwise, they’re all one-dimensional cardboard cutouts. I’m hoping “The Sims 5” is more like The Sims 2 in that regard, where each pre-made character has well-thought-out backgrounds, pre-existing relationships with other Sims, family trees… etc.,  
Overall, I’m happy with the gameplay; the game itself looks beautiful, they continue to do a great job with the expansion packs, stuff packs, and kids -- it’s clear the devs have a lot of love for the franchise and are doing a great job.

I was a huge The Sims fan. I might still be, can't tell based on the Sims 4. I'm quite hyped for Paralives and LifeByYou though, so I truly believe that I still am in love with the genre. The thing is: The Sims 4 is by far, not even close, the worst experience someone could have. At first I thought, ok, this is The Sims 2.5, but IT ISN'T. It is so much worse than The Sims 2 that I regret ever trying to compare them.
Why this is so bad, you say? Well, here are a few things:
- Even though it has been a while (10 years), I won't EVER FORGET that this """"life simulation"""" game DID NOT HAVE POOLS or BABIES when it launched.
- It is a major steback from its previous iterations yes, considering: ALL THREE previous iterations. It does not feature open world or customization like The Sims 3 had, the features it has were SO MUCH better on The Sims 2 (rental apartments, business, night life, etc). Hell, even The Sims (1) was better in all aspects.
- It feels like every "expansion" is charged twice what it was in The Sims 3 but worth a third of what it delivers. See the December 2023 Expansion, For Rent, that is just so bad. As another commentary said, they ruined apartments: TWICE!.
- EA should never be on the helm of this game. It is a cash grab. That's all it is.
- Allegedely, many "choices" were considering players performance, however this game doesn't perfom well enough to justify any of these choices. Every Expansion, Kit or DLC in general comes ridden with bugs that aren't fixed for a while.
- Customization falls flat. After playing The Sims 3 you can't just ignore the abyssal difference between them.,
- Life simulation is weak at best. Yes, you have some options (after spending more than 300 dollars on this, of course), but they are just bland.

It saddens me to be writing this, but it is the truth. I truly hope that either Paralives or Life By You destroy The Sims or that EA is not involved at all with the next iteration of this franchise.

Rest In Peace, The Sims. Thanks for the memories.

The Sims franchise has become so convoluted and enormous that it takes up practically an entire computer. I cannot remove the proprietary clothing outfits that I dislike. In The Sims 3, you could delete the outfits you didn't like so they didn't clog up your entire game. That should be left in. I should have full control of the wardrobe of my sims. I hate the toddler phase and then they went and lengthened it with an ENTIRE expansion.  Instead of the toddler crap only being part of the expansion, it affected everyone's game. If someone asked me my opinion, I would tell them to avoid it simply because of that.  But then the franchise goes and makes things worse. The University and High School expansions are pointless and pretty universally hated, so I managed to avoid that garbage.  Thankfully none of that entered into general gameplay.  I sorta think I might like the horse ranch expansion, but every expansion comes with more crap to dislike. Are they even asking what people want? Shouldn't the horses have come out with the pets?  The money grasping is pathetic. Especially when they have, in the past, made a point of STEALING the original creations of their fan base.  This is the last Sims game I will purchase.  Hope that helps.

The graphics and mood systems are a solid improvement over the Sims 3, especially when creating a Sim, but the regressions in other areas are impossible to ignore. 

This game isn't an upgrade, its a series of trade-offs instead. For every great feature in Sims 4, you lose something great from Sims 3. The removal of the open world hurting the most.

Its still a good game and fun, but the pricing is absolutely wack for the DLCs, not to the mention the DLC content is either stuff that was included in the Sims 3 base game, or comes as 3-4 separate DLCs that would've been a single DLC for Sims 3.

The Sims 4 is an extraordinary masterpiece that engulfs players in an enchanting world of endless possibilities. From the moment I launched the game, I was captivated by its beautiful aesthetics, intricate details, and immersive gameplay.

One of the most remarkable aspects of The Sims 4 is the level of customization it offers. From creating unique and diverse Sims to designing breathtaking houses, the game provides an unparalleled degree of personalization. I spent hours meticulously crafting my Sims' appearances, personalities, and aspirations, and the result was an astonishing array of digital characters that felt alive.

The gameplay itself is incredibly engaging, with a plethora of activities and interactions to explore. Whether it's pursuing a dream career, building relationships, or indulging in hobbies, The Sims 4 offers a rich and dynamic virtual life experience. The emotions system adds a layer of realism, as my Sims showcased a wide range of feelings, from ecstatic highs to melancholic lows, making their stories all the more compelling.

The expansion packs and game updates further enhance the gameplay, introducing new worlds, careers, and activities. Each expansion pack feels like a whole new adventure, expanding the possibilities and providing fresh content to explore. The attention to detail in these expansions is astounding, and they seamlessly integrate into the base game, expanding the already vast universe of The Sims 4.

Moreover, the vibrant and lively community surrounding The Sims 4 is a testament to its enduring appeal. From sharing creations on the Gallery to participating in challenges and events, the game fosters a sense of belonging and creativity. Interacting with fellow Simmers adds an extra layer of enjoyment, as we exchange stories, tips, and inspiration.

I must also commend the developers for their ongoing support and commitment to the game. Regular updates, bug fixes, and content additions demonstrate their dedication to providing an exceptional gaming experience. It's evident that they listen to the community's feedback, constantly striving to improve and refine the game.

In conclusion, The Sims 4 is a true gem in the world of gaming. With its stunning visuals, endless customization options, immersive gameplay, and a devoted community, it offers an unparalleled virtual life experience. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or new to the world of The Sims, this game is an absolute must-play. Prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey where your imagination is the only limit!

The Sims is a great game to boost your imagination. Something we often leave behind as adults.  I'm just sad that there is no longer an online version that allows you to communicate with others worldwide. I love that the game still allows for external mods and media.  That was my favorite part from the earlier versions.  And there is an entire community of creators giving away and selling objects, skins, buildings, and clothing for the game. 

My only issue is with the game-play glitches or anomalies. Like, for example, where children are involved. I don't know if its a glitch, or something that is a result of personality and mood, but oftentimes, commands by parents aren't followed.  Something like putting a baby in its crib or in their highchair, gets ignored, or delayed. I find myself having to simplify the tasks in order to get things done, by first selecting, pick up child, then place child in high chair, then give child food.  This shouldn't be the case if there is an option when clicking on the highchair that says, "give food to (child)."  Stuff like this makes it hard to provide proper care and prevent CPS from taking your kid away for neglect.

First of all, this is a good game now that it's free. However, I got this game way back when it was a purchase, and EA didn't have the balls to give me any free stuff that I could have enjoyed.

Second, I would like (and do) hate the Infants update with all of my heart.. It's a useless lifestage where you literally just make babies try a new food on their path to adulthood, and it was probably made to get more people onboard or old players back online again. Not to mention that this lifestage is hard to control especially when I make parents go to give care to their infant and they don't care and start watching TV instead of feeding their child who hasn't ate food in what seems like two weeks.

Third, I hate how most of the stuff that should be in the base game is in DLCs. I don't want to pay $20 to get a stupid DLC that makes my sims able to eat out. I don't want to pay $40 just to have slightly more job options. I don't want to pay $10 to let my sims live in a tiny home. I don't want to pay $5 for extra patio furniture. I don't want to pay $40 for cats and dogs and a crappy videogame remake of New England.

Lastly, make some of these **DEBUG** items in the game. Sims should be able to drive cars, at the least. In The Sims 3 you could buy a car **in the base game.** Road signs should be available in build mode without cheats.

In conclusion, EA, make this game better.

There's not a whole lot I can say, other than I'm a Sims fan. I haven't played very many Sims prior to this game (I played one of them on the Nintendo 3DS a couple years back for a short time), but I definitely knew this was my type of game. I love controlling every little aspect of their lives, and with tons of clothing, personality, and action choices to choose from, that certainly vibes great with me.

I can't say I know what I'm missing with all of those DLCs I've never thought about purchasing. Other than the most obvious (for me) being the worlds that they can live in. Only starting off with a measly three worlds seems more than a little money-grabby when there are, I think, about ten locked in the uber-expensive DLCs. Other than that, I don't really feel like I'm missing much. I feel like they would be great for people who really love the Sims and wouldn't mind laying down more than a little bit of money, but I think the base game works for me for what I wanted to do from the beginning. It's just a silly little game that I don't mind wasting my time on.

7/10

paper thin as a game, mediocre as a simulation, good as a building sandbox if you load it up with mods to overcome the lack of base assets.  i can't help but feel resentment when i boot up the game and am buffeted with ads for the latest $30 DLC microexpansion, but now that the game is free maybe new players won't feel as strongly.

Yes, the Sims aren't what they used to be anymore, and a lot of people will probably even say that The Sims 4 isn't worth the money.

Yet, as someone who grew up with Sims 2 and especially Sims 3, this game just brings back my nostalgia and manages to make me happy, even though I wish they would've just taken Sims 3 and given it better graphics.🙄

It's addictive, and I haven't found any game that is similar to it at the moment. It helps me unwind after a stressful day and calms me down while I love creating detailed stories and plots for each sim of mine!

I do have to say that the prices of the expansion packs or any kind of pack are way too expensive for what they contain. That's why I recommend buying them whenever they're on sale instead of purchasing them at their original price. It saved me quite a lot of money that I was able to spend on other games instead. 🤔🤤

It's decent enough fun for a few hours while you're just setting up the basics. Building a house, training skills, going to work (the same as every Sims game). But when that gets boring you'll need to start draining your savings for all the DLC to get to some actual content. Which is basically the same content that EA has been re-releasing since Sims 1 and 2. It's kind of nuts that the bulk of all expansion ideas came out of those two games. Anything original after that boils down to adapting those ideas for a revised control scheme, or dressing them up a little to jive with current cultural trends. Neither of which really justifies the price staying the same or increasing.

If ALL the DLC was capped at like $150 (full price), I'd probably own a fair chunk of it by now. But instead I've spent nothing beyond the retail price I paid for the base game when it came out (pre-Steam). EA must be really raking it in from the few people who'll occasionally buy a couple DLC packs, or those who dish out for all of it, because alienating regular players hasn't bothered them since Sims 3 which follows the same DLC structure, and the base game is now free.

The Sims 4 is a strange experience. It can be incredibly fun, tedious, nutty, mundane, etc within just a 24 hour in-game cycle. I enjoy it acknowledging its many-- MANY flaws. The game regularly stops operating the way it's supposed to. Or the opposite and your game gets stuck in a cycle that can only be stopped with mods or closing the whole thing. But clearly, as you can see from my play time, the Sims 4 deserves my praise. The possibilities are literally endless [considering you're willing to shell out hundreds of dollars for DLC] and there is no play-through like the last. Just as long as you can enjoy the game for what it is rather than letting the constant negativity of The Sims fandom weigh you down, it's worth just downloading it for free. Hope you enjoy everything after that :]

I have owned every single Sims game and several of the DLC for Sims 2 and 3, so this review is based on many years of Sims game-play. 
The base game is good, it runs so much smoother than Sims 3 did, and is everything you'd want out of a basic Sims game. But that's the problem, its basic and all the best parts of the game are locked away behind the most expensive set of DLC on the market. EA has once again engaged in predatory practices akin to their loot box scandals by taking what should be part of the Sims 4 base game and made it accessible only via DLC. So, if you want the most basic model of The Sims ever made, get this one, it is really good at being basic. But if you don't want to pay the cost of a brand new game for each DLC, then skip this one and stick with Sims 3.

The Sims 4 is an immersive life simulation that excels in offering creative freedom and personalization. Its robust Build Mode and Create-a-Sim tools empower players to design unique homes and craft diverse, detailed characters. The game's depth lies in guiding these Sims through life stages, making impactful decisions, and exploring various aspirations, careers, and relationships. With a plethora of expansions seamlessly integrating new experiences and a vibrant community, The Sims 4 remains a captivating journey into boundless creativity and engaging storytelling, making it a must-play for fans of simulation and creative expression.

EA really doesn't deserve a positive review on this one, even through my attempts to look at the positives here. I played a lot of Sims 2 and Sims 3 back in their prime and it was a ton of fun. Sims 4 has a lot of standout features over the previous in it's own right, but at least the others felt like a game and not a glorified dollhouse. 

Sims 4 has removed one of my favorite features from 3, and that is Custom Worlds as well as being able to place lots where-ever, personal nitpick though as the worlds in TS4 look pretty good. 
Of course there is more, Custom Swatches is gone. Even if this was cut in favor of performance, there are so many workarounds to this, even if there are a decent selection of pre-existing colors that you can choose for each separate piece i.e. independently color the sheets and frame of a bed. I question the game performance aspect because the PAINT TOOL exsists on pets, werewolves, ect... 
And to tie it all together, you don't really have as much movement freedom going around the world. What happens is you have 1 active lot at a time and you may only move around the pre-determined neighborhood (1/3 of the current world). Doing what sims 3 might have had a performance impact for sure, but either allow seamless lot transitions in an active neighborhood or just open up the world to wander if you so choose.

TS4 has some good qualities it can be commended for.
Moods and Multitasking make the game quite dynamic, giving sims more liveliness in everyday life, much needed change.
The game runs smooth as far as I am concerned, the older games are much harder to run and were never optimized well to be honest. Still think some much needed features like custom swatches/color wheel can be afforded.
Most aspects of the game look good and were designed well for what I feel the sims is. This can vary between people but the cleaner style is quite the step up from TS3's honestly hard to look at visuals.

DLC... Only good thing I can say is the content adds some decent variety, if it were a reasonable price. TS4 recently went free, but that does NOT excuse the NUMEROUS $40 expansion packs $20 game packs and $10 stuff packs. Oh that's not enough, they decided to add $5 of useless BS that is the kits?? If EA had just bundled many of the features from between the several packs like TS3 they MIGHT be worth their price, let me list a few examples;
City Living + Get Famous
High School Years + Discover University
Cats & Dogs + Horse Ranch + My First Pet
Werewolves + Vampires + Realm of Magic + Paranormal
Growing Together + Get Together + Parenthood + The various kid/toddler stuff packs
Honestly some features should have been in the base game from the start, Especially core features such as Seasons, the Generations type packs, and even the more generic packs, which most packs are especially as you get lower into Game and Stuff packs. Bare-bones features like Lunar Cycles, infants and more get added in a free update, but they have near zero uses without their corresponding packs. The packs all together are about $1,000 off sale (Please do not pay full price for these packs). There is no use in saying boycotting them will do anything because EA has several egregious money making methods. This series is fun, there just needs to be a bigger uproar to stir up EA...

I've been playing the Sims series for pretty much my entire life. Started with the OG Sims, and played pretty much all the games but the DS game and SimCity. I've always loved the games. While I do recommend playing Sims 4, there's a couple things about it I loathe.
  1. In Sims 3, you could make pretty much ANY color swatch you wanted. They got rid of that in Sims 4.
  2. The pack prices, primarily the larger packs, are insane. Yes, you get a bunch of content but with as buggy as they are when released (and then those bugs are almost never fixed) it doesn't add up. With buying ALL the packs, (Not including tax, and rounding the numbers for easy math) it costs (USD) $1155 in TOTAL to be able to buy EVERY pack (not including base game, which is free).
There's probably a few other things, but those are the overall main issues. I understand that this is a BIG game for EA/Maxis, but still, such a money grab that's missing some of the BEST features from previous games. Do I still overall recommend it? Absolutely, but only if you a) have the money to be forking out for all the packs, or b) you have the willpower to ONLY use base game (plus free content) and CC.

dlc unlocker is the best

I bought this game around release and it was honestly very disappointing. Now, almost a decade later, it's improved immensely and the fact that it's now free is just amazing. The amount of time you can invest into this game is ridiculous. It can sometimes take a bit of imagination and roleplaying, but you'd be surprised at how far you can take the game. I'm a much bigger fan of the model Maxis have gone for for this release where they make the core game free to play and sell DLC expansions.

The Sims 4 has constantly been a love/hate relationship ever since I've first started playing. More so of the Hate side anymore. I focus on the house building aspect of the game. One of my favorite things to do. But between the lazy DLC items in Buy/Build Mode where purchased DLCs will copy the same item from base game or other DLCs and vaguely change it's color and then add it as a "NEW" item or and the vast number of bugs while not using CC is outrageous for a game that is over 9 year old. 

Reason for Uninstalling this game as of 12/12/23 after having over 460 hours in game is as follows. I've spent the last 5 hours creating a house and going into the deep detailing work to make it look "lived in". Saving the game often because the Sims 4 will randomly crash while running on a RTX 3070, I7, 64GB of RAM, and all being stored on 4TB SSD. Only to have the game not save. "Save" function, "Save As" function was utilized as well as the "Save and Quit" function. I relaunched my game hours later, loading in from my "Save As" file and the house and all my work not be saved. Not the first time this has happened either.

I'm done with trying to get in touch with EA's lack of a support team over these issues. Now I'm just out the $$$ that I've spent on this broken, unfinished, overpriced, money hungry game. But it's been a learning experience to not trust yet another AAA development studio.

I'm sorry but I can no longer fully recommend this game.

Since they opted to go Free-to-play (F2P) the game has turned into a content cash grab.  None of the recent releases since F2P have been worth anything, they seem to be short on content and high on price.  Even "wait for a sale" is few and far in-between.  I just no longer will put money into the game, which is sad because I had pretty much all of the content until they went free. So past state pre-F2P - 5/5 stars.  Current state since F2P - 1/5 stars.

A Virtual Utopia Unleashed! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

I've been an avid fan of The Sims series since its inception, and The Sims 4 has truly taken the virtual simulation experience to new heights. This game is nothing short of a masterpiece, earning a solid five stars in my book!

From the moment you dive into the game, you're greeted with stunning visuals and an incredible attention to detail. The graphics are crisp, the animations are fluid, and the overall design is a testament to the developers' commitment to creating a visually immersive world.

One of the standout features of The Sims 4 is the Create a Sim (CAS) system. The level of customization available is mind-blowing. Whether you want to recreate yourself, your favorite celebrity, or let your imagination run wild with fantastical characters, the possibilities are virtually endless. The addition of diverse hairstyles, clothing options, and accessories ensures that every Sim is a unique expression of your creativity.

The game also excels in its simulation of life itself. The emotions system adds a new layer of depth to your Sims' experiences. Watching them express a wide range of emotions, from joy to sorrow, truly makes them feel like living, breathing entities. The introduction of multitasking further enhances the realism, allowing your Sims to juggle various activities seamlessly.

Building and furnishing your Sim's home is another area where The Sims 4 shines. The Build/Buy mode provides an extensive array of tools and options, making it easy to create everything from cozy cottages to sprawling mansions. The inclusion of expansion packs expands these possibilities even further, offering new worlds, careers, and gameplay elements that keep the experience fresh and exciting.

The modding community for The Sims 4 is also worth noting. The support for player-created content has led to an incredible array of mods that enhance and extend the game in ways that were previously unimaginable. Whether you're looking for new hairstyles, custom furniture, or entirely new gameplay mechanics, the modding community has you covered.

In conclusion, The Sims 4 is a triumph in the simulation genre. It's a game that continues to evolve and captivate players with its endless possibilities. If you haven't experienced the joy of creating and guiding your Sims through life, you're missing out on one of the most delightful and engaging gaming experiences available. Five stars well-deserved! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

As I've spent some time playing this game and got my mother into it, who has this year alone ranked up over 1000 hours' worth of playtime, this review will combine both a new and "older" player's opinion and insight. 

If you're considering getting the game - just get it. I got it when it was still paid for and though I am still a bit salty about paying for it a few months prior to the game becoming free-to-play, both my mother and I have had a lot of fun with this game. Never hurts to try something new. Just YOLO it. 

Now, there are a lot (and I mean a lot) of DLCs and packs to buy should you enjoy the game to the point of wanting to invest more money on it, and you can add free mods for both tangible (hairstyles/furniture) and intangible things (personality traits, etc.) from online websites (just make sure you have anti-virus/-malware software just in case). Mods are also easy to add to your game, I mean the program files literally already starts with a folder for mods so you're good to go quick and easy. I've added some mods I've found add to immersion quite nicely, whereas my mother prefers the DLCs and finds them perfectly suitable to what she wants from the game. 

We all know EA and how they are, micro-transactions are the air they breathe. I agree that some DLCs should honestly have been base game features, e.g. Seasons, but honestly I understand why they're add-ons instead. Especially from a new player's POV. 

Of course, some sims's actions are also buggy/lacking. Unless I explicitly tell my sim mothers to care for their gremlin-like offspring, they just play video games all day and leave everything to dad. Sims WILL put their dirty plates/glasses on half walls and coffee tables, then complain about not being able to reach them. For a game as old as this, there's no reason why this should still be considered acceptable, but this will all depend on what you play the game for so this is really just me nitpicking.

If you loved Sims 2 and hated Sims 3, you will probably enjoy Sims 4. It has a feel a little closer to that of Sims 2 but with Sims 3  levels of customization. And doesn't have the constant game braking bugs Sims 3 had AND you can use all your expansions instead of just one or two like Sims 3 tries to get you to do.

Additionally you can switch between households like you could in Sims 2 much easier than Sims 3 without the degradation of work/school performance. You'll just have to make sure you un-select the household you switched from so they don't age or anything. Time won't be frozen for them like it was in Sims 2 but it's still much closer to that so if your Sims have multiple generations and you want to hop around them you can.

It's after you play for a while and decide you want to start doing things, that  you realize you actually can't do sh** until you buy some DLC. I've owned all of them since Sims 1 and when a new iteration comes out it's invariably amazing.  Except its been around a decade I think and still no Sims 5.  
Every single person I showed this game to and tried playing became instantly hooked and almost had to be pried away from the keyboard.  The only minor complaint I have about this game is, your players are not puppet-like and are too slow to do the things you click for them to do.  That means you winde up getting behind on the minor chores like cooking, which I hate, and bathroom stuff which has to come out of some other activity that's actually interesting. 

Now there are a ton of cheats and mods to make your Sims do what you want it to and those do make the game much better.  BUT this is a game that EA seems to mod on a monthly if not weekly basis, all of which seem to trash or at least disable your mods.  So every time EA makes the most minor update you have to re-download your favorite mods and do it all over again while hoping the mod is compatible with the latest useless update.  
Other than those irksome issues this game is amazing and almost magical at times (you can get actual magic with the Supernatural update).  My favorite update was Pets, those really add very much to the game and if I had only one ex-pack Pets would be it.

Get lost in another life. The Sims 4 is a very fun game to get lost in. During the isolation of Covid, this game was a way to "live" while stuck inside. Be warned, however, the Sims 4 has a ton of DLC and one can invest hundreds (and hundreds) of $s. 

The best way to play is to figure out which expansions to invest in is to figure out what you want to invest your Sim time in. There are things that you can decide to do, but the expansions tend to also create obligations that your Sim MUST do (or face unpleasant consequences). For example, I hate cleaning IRL, so chasing after dust bunnies in a game did not seem like a heck of a lot of fun to me. So I didn't get that DLC. I do like laundry though, so I got that DLC. I love building and relationships and pets (I'm a dog person), so I got the expansions for those. I hated high school in real life, so did not get that expansion, and thought college kids were annoying IRL, so skipped that as well. But if you love the younger person drama and hijinks, those are the must have expansions! I also like the paranormal aspects like werewolves, vampires, and ghosts! Got those, too! I like to explore and spend time, so I have my settings set for longer time and longer lives (seriously, the Grim Reaper visits are hard after investing a lot of time in your Sims), but there are DLCs where you can get medicines and potions to expand the lives for your Sims. 

Some of the smaller add ons can be fun if you love to decorate or dress your Sims, and many of those add ons are under $15. Fashion isn't really my thing so I skip a lot of the designer specific dlc. Great for fashionistas though who want to spend a lot of time making their Sims sparkle. Also, there are add ons with decorating fun elements. I got quite a few of those because I love decorating. Don't forget the Sims community also has a lot of free content and builds! Check it out.

Sims 4 is a great game, and as long as you are willing to invest only in what really interests you, you can have a lot of fun creating a Sim life! If, however, you are a person who MUST have all of the DLC of a game, you are probably going to be disappointed by the expense. Sales happen several times a year (best times to buy new content) and there are occasional freebies, too. Learn how to adjust your settings if things are going too fast or too slow for you (there are several layers like day length, week/month/season/year length, and lifetime length). The speed of a life or the speed of a game can easily be changed to your gaming style. Also, know that certain expansions and add ons open up personal aspects in families, relationships, and life/afterlife. Invest wisely. Have fun in your new Sims lives!

Every player will have a very different experience, so I don’t see why I wouldn’t recommend giving it a try at least.

I had a really good time building and designing houses. It’s fun picking a starter home to decorate and then making progress in building your dream home. Perhaps if I was a more creative sim architect I’d point out some flaws but for now, that won’t be necessary.

As for playing family-oriented sims, I wish it wasn’t so slow-going. The family aspiration is hard-won because there is so much lacking when it comes to babies and children that we know there’s no way it won’t impact their personality depth when they get older, and it is such a bummer for family-oriented sims. Unfortunately, story mode or rolling the dice to select a toddler trait can’t replace the plenty of missing features that would solve this problem.

There is a decent game here, even better with mods. Just, EA never puts the DLCs on good sales. For a game this old, some of this stuff should be sub $5-$10 but they still want to charge more for it. Ridiculous!

Sims 5 is looking to be multiplayer and likely a hot mess so this is to be the last decent Sims game if you love the series. The multiplayer element is probably going to get all screwy with the mods and most likely EA will do all the hosting so that will limit mods even more. 

If you have to get the DLC, buy it on Steam, not EA. Why? Because there are some little quirks to how it activates if you try to play through steam with dlc from EA. This especially effects Mac users which don't have a functional version outside of Origin at this moment. However, if you load it direct from Steam first, it applies to your EA account without issue.

Ultimately, run some decent sales EA and then I'll recommend!

Been playing and loving the Sims games from the beginning and while this is definitely a step down from Sims 3 it's still good fun. Besides, not many other games in this genre exist for some reason so eh, I'll take what I can get.

Pros: It's now free to play. It's not the worst game ever. It's fairly easy. It has a pretty good selection of custom content including new mechanics such as mental illness and a pretty robust healthcare mod. Pretty good build mode.  The DLC is pretty A la carte

Cons: Simulation Lag is probably my biggest issue with this game, Your Sims can go IRL minutes without doing what they were queued to do. The Modding community is pretty toxic, you can get banned from certain communities by downloading the wrong mods by the wrong creators. Some even has spyware to doxx people. There is way too much DLC. 

TLDR. Be careful around the modding scene for this game, there are more than a few psychos. Also do research into the DLC and figure out what you want and don't want. I'd also wait for a sale when it comes to DLC. 

I also won't be surprised if this review gets taken down due to me mentioning the mod community

I wouldn't recommend buying this corporate cash grab under any circumstances. The base game is a skeleton of an experience that requires the purchase of a heaping ton of DLC to make it 

The Sims 4 is a heartless corporate cash grab in which I have regret for every single penny that I wasted on this game. The base game is a skeletal, bland experience that fails to capture any of the charm that the earlier games in the series had. Do you want a better experience? In the typical fashion for EA, you can buy their dozens of DLC that [i]should've[/i] been in the base game for the price of a full game so that you can have incremental improvements in your experience! Would you like to have seasons and holidays in your game? Please hand over [i]$40[/i] for this improvement. Would you like some basic improvements to the behavior of children so that they aren't lifeless blobs? Another $40, please. 

To experience the full game, you must have a stack of money that is burning a hole in your pocket. Overall, I wouldn't recommend purchasing this to anyone. It would be best to purchase The Sims 3 instead.

The game is fine. The EA store is a nightmare and unfortunately buying on steam does not get you out of having to deal with the EA store. My daughter is generally the one who plays the Sims and I have a separate account for her. After spending over an hour trying to get it to work, I never managed to make it possible for her to play in her account after I bought the game in my account. A lot of the steam features don't work because steam can't really start the game, but only the EA store. For example, family view doesn't work and you just always have to get out of family view. Fortunately I don't own any games that I'm that upset about my daughter having access to. 

I hate to say it, but I recommend buying on the EA store rather than steam. That way you will at least only have to deal with the EA store and not the hassle of linked account.

I like this game. Its getting very close to being a modern version of the sims 3 which was a beloved fan favorite. The build buy mode is very good, the stories and emotional moments are fairly detailed. 

The sims retaining memory of interactions with other sims is spot on. They cleaned up this game from its released state and it should be acknowledged or at least appreciated. 

The DLC is over course there and is overpriced. But the DLC does add a ton of features in some cases and interactions in the world itself. It took me about four years to get the DLC that I have by just buying one or two when on sale.

I use mods to add personality and some other minor tweaks to the game personally. Custom content being able to be imported into the game without any programming knowledge or having to literally the fight game to get it and working is a total plus to this game. It even allowed you to use custom content by checking it in the options menu. 

Over all I really enjoy this game for it is what it was meant to be, a life simulator in a fictional world that has  no modern day issues such as gore, violence, ect.

I love this game to bits but I'm getting really tired of the microtransactions and DLC costing as much as it does or having barely anything in them to justify the price, especially older ones, hell I'm getting tired of having to pay for packs when I already bought the game twice since my last computer got permanently logged out of my steam account before the base game was made free to play. I also wish they fixed some scaling issues for people that need to have the text size up like myself and put a disable flash option as I'm unable to play during thunderstorms or take pictures via the simphone because of flash effects. I'm really happy they are including more cultures into the game but it feels a bit weird having to fork over 40 bucks to experience my own culture in the sims. I'm still waiting on the disability rep they promised us 8 years ago as currently there is only hearing aids, scars and insulin pumps and I'd really like my sim to represent what I look like in real life as a wheelchair and mobility aid user, without having to use CC. They also need to work on the warping and weird texture glitches that happen when having a plus size sim as its a relatively easy fix and discouraging to see they haven't addressed it yet as of me writing this. I'd definitely recommend the base game to pretty much anyone who has a device that can run it but try not to get roped into buying the packs, especially the kits as I don't feel the kits are worth the cost. Some of the older hair textures do need redoing as they don't match the new hairs. TLDR more inclusion and bug fixes, less microtransations please.

I've loved every version of The Sims since its inception. I love watching my Sims start families that can grow into dynasties (the family tree is great for me to see and plan out what to do with which Sim)! I so enjoy being able to customise each toon; I like that they now have wants and long term goals, like conquering fears, getting married, or even cramming for an exam. I like how different they are from one to the next, and they don't have the same old conversations... now there are so many choices for conversation! I never get bored. From designing properties to dynastic families (and an ever increasing amount of beautiful, creative DLC from gallery), this game encompasses everything to keep me playing for 1000 more hours.

Do not get this. I know it's free, but it's not even worth the space on your PC. The EA App (required to launch the game) is utterly unusable, meaning that if you, like me, spent money on this, you won't be getting what you paid for. Or anything at all, for that matter, since the launcher doesn't actually launch anything.

Origin was meh but worked; it was an app you'd only ever launch to play a game that required it. But it launched. That's unfortunately more than can be said for the current EA App 80% of the time or more. When it does launch, you have to log in manually every single time, no matter if you opt-in to remembering your login or not. The process to start a game looks like this:

1. Click game icon
2. Wait several minutes for the app to load
3. If you're lucky and it doesn't immediately CTD, you're prompted to login or sign up
4. Type in your login information (typically after going through the painful password reset process)
5. Since you bought the game on Steam, it opens your browser and asks you to login to that too
6. Log in to Steam (including two-factor authentication)
7. Close the browser; about 50% of the time, the app will not register that you logged in and you'll need to repeat steps 5 & 6. 
8. The EA App is finally opened! (After a minute or two of loading...)
9. Click the tile of the game you already clicked the tile of in step 1
10. Wait for the game to launch. If you're lucky, I assume you get to play the game after this step
11. Retry steps 9 & 10 until you realize it's been three hours since you started this journey and you haven't even seen the logo of the game you wanted to play.
12. Decide you never want to purchase from EA again.

Anyway, save your time and energy; play literally anything else. I've only been able to open this game once since the 'upgrade' to the EA App in March, and that was via a workaround that has since been fixed - instead of spending time making the app usable so that such workarounds were unnecessary, they spent it making the workarounds unusable too, leaving players like me without the product we paid for. Don't support this garbage fire.

Title: Life, Creativity, and Endless Possibilities in The Sims™ 4

Rating: ★★★★☆

The Sims™ 4, developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts, continues the legacy of the beloved life simulation franchise. As the fourth installment in the series, it brings a mix of familiar gameplay elements and innovative features, offering players a chance to create, control, and customize the lives of virtual characters in a virtual world.

Gameplay and Creativity (★★★★☆):
The core gameplay of The Sims™ 4 revolves around creating and managing your Sims' lives. The game excels in providing players with the tools to craft unique, diverse, and intriguing characters. The Create-A-Sim tool is incredibly robust, allowing for a high degree of customization in terms of appearance, clothing, and even personality traits. The same level of detail extends to building and furnishing houses, with an intuitive building system that allows for creative architectural designs.

The Sims themselves exhibit a wide range of emotions and interactions, adding depth to their virtual lives. You can guide them through various activities, careers, and relationships. This aspect of The Sims™ 4 is where it truly shines, as it's a sandbox of creativity where your imagination is the limit.

Expansions and Content (★★★★☆):
Over the years, The Sims™ 4 has seen numerous expansion packs, game packs, and stuff packs, each introducing new features, content, and themes. These expansions enhance the gameplay experience, offering additional careers, locations, and customization options. While they do come at an extra cost, they significantly enrich the world of The Sims and provide ample replay value.

Visuals and Performance (★★★★☆):
The game boasts a visually appealing, colorful, and well-optimized environment. It runs smoothly on most systems, offering a visually pleasing experience with detailed character animations and realistic interactions. The graphic style is more streamlined than previous titles, which some may prefer, but others might miss the depth and complexity of earlier games.

Modding Community (★★★★☆):
One of the remarkable aspects of The Sims™ 4 is its thriving modding community. Players have created countless custom content, from hairstyles and clothing to custom careers and complete overhaul mods. This extends the game's life and versatility, allowing you to tailor your experience to your liking.

Issues (★★★☆☆):
While The Sims™ 4 is a fantastic game, it's not without its issues. Some players have voiced concerns about the number of expansion packs and the cost of keeping up with all the content. Additionally, some players have noticed minor bugs and quirks in the game, although Maxis has been proactive in releasing updates to address them.

Overall (★★★★☆):
The Sims™ 4 is a charming and immersive life simulation game that excels in providing players with a canvas for creativity and storytelling. Its extensive customization options, coupled with expansions and a dedicated modding community, make it a delightful experience. While it may not be a radical departure from its predecessors, it refines and enhances the core gameplay of the franchise. Whether you're a long-time Sims fan or a newcomer, The Sims™ 4 offers a virtual world where you can let your imagination run wild and shape the lives of your Sims in endlessly fascinating ways.

Welcome to the wacky, whimsical world of The Sims 4, where you can experience all the excitement of real life, without any of the consequences. It's like being in charge of a virtual ant farm, but instead of ants, you have these quirky, pixelated creatures with a penchant for drama.

In The Sims 4, you're not just a player; you're a deity, creating and controlling the lives of your Sims with a mischievous glint in your eye. It's like playing a game of puppetry, except your puppets occasionally catch fire while trying to cook mac and cheese.

The customization in this game is wilder than a costume party at a zoo. You can create Sims that resemble your neighbors, your favorite celebrities, or even your weirdest dreams. It's like a bizarre episode of "Let's Make a Deal" where you get to choose what's behind door number three.

But it's not all fun and games. You'll be managing the day-to-day lives of your Sims, making sure they eat, sleep, and occasionally find time to use the bathroom. It's like babysitting a group of hyperactive kids who are inexplicably obsessed with grilled cheese sandwiches.

The humor in The Sims 4 comes from the unpredictable chaos that ensues when you give your Sims free will. They'll do things you'd never expect, like painting awkward self-portraits or trying to swim in a pool with no ladder. It's like watching a sitcom where the characters constantly surprise you with their absurdity.

In conclusion, The Sims 4 is the game that lets you play god in the most hilarious way possible. So, whether you want to build the perfect suburban family or create a household of misfits, dive in and prepare for a rollercoaster of emotions, from joy to frustration, with a side of uncontrollable laughter.

This is an amazing game about life. We all struggle someway or somehow, so lets put all our struggle on the screen with my #1 game about life: The Sims 4. The Sims is a great game about life. For instance, you can be a parent, or not have any kids, you can be famous (you have to get a DLC), you can own your very own horse/goat/sheep ranch (you have to get a DLC), get a job and earn money, adopt a cat or a dog (you have to get a DLC), learn to snowboard/ski (you have to get a DLC), be a mermaid (you have to get a DLC), be a werewolf (you have to get a DLC), be a vampire (you have to get a DLC), be a wizard/witch (you have to get a DLC), and SO much more! I love this game so much and is probably my #2 most played game on steam. Any questions ask below and I will get to them as quick as humanly possible!

Started out single. Life goals told me to find a lover and start a family. Picked the nearest sim, got to know them, married them, had some children together.

Needed a new life goal. Started focusing on the job and on money. Spouse and kids were too time consuming, I ignored them to focus on myself. After that success, I found that I no longer needed to sleep, leaving me more time to ignore them and become stronger.

New life goal. Have many romantic partners. Started kissing and woohooing anything that moved. Spouse caught me and interrupted me. I divorced them to get them out of the way so I could get a Gold on my date. Now I no longer require food.

New life goal. Have enemies. May as well pick whoever dislikes me the most. It's my ex. Yelled at them, insulted them, beat them up five times. They felt very sad and then very angry. I no longer need to go to the bathroom.

Last goal of that lifetime wish. Watch someone die. I picked the nearest sim. It was my ex. Apparently they were my neighbor all along, which is why they always seemed to be nearby. Not anymore. Dead now. I watched it happen. I no longer need to shower. Not even to get their blood off my hands.

Next life goal. Have a big house. I move into the my former neighbor/spouse's house because it is available and bigger. I have now taken their life and their house. I adopt some kids. They were mine. I forgot about the kids. They don't know that I did nothing while watching their other parent die. Doesn't matter, I fulfill another life goal. Now I am an eternally happy and fulfilled immortal psychopath.

The Sims™ 4

Infinite Creativity: The Sims is all about letting your imagination run wild. From designing unique characters with distinct personalities and appearances to building and customizing dream homes, the game provides an expansive canvas for creativity.

Endless Gameplay: The sheer number of expansion packs, stuff packs, and mods available for The Sims ensures that the game never gets stale. Whether you want to explore different careers, engage in romantic relationships, or simply enjoy the daily lives of your Sims, there's always something new to discover.

Accessible to All Ages: The Sims is a family-friendly game that appeals to a wide audience. Its easy-to-learn mechanics make it accessible to younger players, while its depth and complexity offer a rewarding experience for adults.

Engaging Social Dynamics: Watching your Sims interact with each other and the world around them is both humorous and engaging. The social dynamics and quirky behaviors of your virtual citizens can lead to surprising and entertaining situations.
