ETA: Reject Sims 4, return to Sims 3
Oh boy, where do I even start?
!The $ims 4 is a sim(s)ulation game that focuses on the characters you create, following them through their journeys as they become adults and create lives of their own. Thats the premise of the base game, Sims 4, which is now free to play. This, in my opinion, was a good idea, the base game is so simple and well basic by itself, and has been refined over the past iterations.
!Personally, I have sunk almost 300 hours into this game and spent many a buck, so please note, this game has a lot more to it when you have money.
-Cons
-Money $ink: now, while Sims 4 base game is now free, there are a lot of DLCs that are almost necessary to play the game. I will go over a few of them now: Seasons, Growing Together and Get to Work. I pick these three because they add very basic things to the game. Seasons add, well, seasons! Don't want to be stuck in a perpetual cycle of "not a season"? Nobody really wants to pay 20+ bucks for something so fundamental. Growing Together is probably my favorite addition due to "family dynamics", which, again, should be just a part of the base game. Get to work adds more interactive jobs, which I really enjoy playing through, even if it is my least used of the three. Modding is very prevalent in this game and I think that is fantastic. Personally, I can't figure out how to get them, but I highly recommend looking into the community. 
!Buy the DLCs only when on sale!
-Customization: Okay, this one may change in the future because the game is constantly evolving and updating, but I highly encourage looking into modders if you find the options are fairly restrictive. Specifically, I wish I could "fine tune" hair the same way I could the face.
-Controls: Out of everything, I think I find the controls with the camera the most irritating. A lot of the time, it just doesn't camera, it doesn't cooperate and it can be annoying. 
-Sims autonomy: Okay, I have autonomy for my household off because I like to direct exactly what is happening. However, the one thing that somehow manages to work by itself is mischief. I cannot express how badly I hate the Mischief skill, but my sims will not stop doing it! That is probably very specific to me, but it is very irritating!
+Pros
+There is so much to do: Want to be a pro athlete and max out the fitness skill? Go for it! Want to have a huge family of 7 kids? Absolutely! Good luck trying to feed them all at the same time, I wish you luck! Want to be a freelance farmer? Make sculptures to sell? Write books?? Absolutely! If you can dream it, you can (probably) do it!
+Customization: I know I picked on this earlier, but there really are so many options, especially with the addition of medical devices, like hearing aids and glucose monitors. There are stretch marks available, top surgery scars, birth marks, freckles even! There are hair styles of different textures, cultures and colors. There are also cultural clothes to pick from! 
!Conclusion
For all of my issues with the game and the franchise in general, I do love this game and I will spend plenty more time playing it.
#TLDR: Cons: DLCs cost a LOT, Controls can be wonky. Pros: There is a lot to do, even just in base game. Pro and Cons: Customization is expansive but can feel restrictive after awhile.

The sims has been in gradual decline since the Sims 3 but at least they made an effort in that game.  Open worlds are gone.  Character traits having any bearing on gameplay or story telling are gone.  graphics are more cartoony, less detailed and less immersive than even Sims 2 animations.

Unless you buy hundreds of dollars worth of DLC there's little if anything to do in the base game.  Most people will have a better time playing Sims 2, which is currently available for free with every DLC included.  Those DLC actually add interesting stuff for your sims to do rather than a series of text boxes that you get in sims 4.

Beware, many of the DLCs are broken so that the key gameplay they're focused on is impossible without cheats.  This is less a sims game than it is a House building game.  The building however is generally a step up from previous game, this is definitely the only are which is an actual improvement.  Aside from some issues with placing stairs and fences you have a lot more flexibility to create vertical levels without needing cheats. 

Some of the missing features were eventually added to the base game (like swimming pools, 4 years after release) but the game still feels empty and lacking without several DLCs.  I mean you'll want at least 5 or 6 to feel like you have a whole game.  Even for FREE the Sims 4 feels like a rip off.  If that seems harsh, I paid $50 AUD on EA store many years ago and have waited a loooong time to see if things got better.

This game is so bad that as a life long fan of Sims 1 and 2 I will not even bother to play any subsequent sequels because its clear that anybody who cared about this game has left the development or is drowned out by EA's cash grabbing management.  2/10  would not recommend.

I didn't play it much but if the Sims 2 is too old school for your tastes try the Sims 3 before wasting your time here.

I've been playing Sims since the 2000s.. While sims 4 is not my favorite. It does give a lot of customization options. The graphics are most crisp than other games (Sims 3... *cough* ) and it doesn't have the options that my FAVORITE sims game had (Sims 2.. I'm looking at you bestie), it is way more modern, not as complicated as other games have been, and I believe it has something for every user. You almost have to buy the expansion packs ( I have A LOT of opinions about all of those lol). Just know that when you buy this, plan to spend a lot of money (mostly if you have no life like I do.. why am I doing these little thought bubbles? Idk. Good for you, for following along) on expansion packs (PARENTHOOD and PETS DOGS AND CATS are a MUST). Depending on your computer depends on how well Sims run. If you have a crappy computer.. it runs crappy (not as crappy as the dial up internet days but yanno), trust me I know. I finally upgraded computers and this game runs like a darn DREAM. What was the point of this.. oh yeah, Sims 4. Stellar game that I was 100s of hours on because I like to disassociate from reality. 10/10 would recommend.

Sims 4: Where My Zbra Sim Became a Criminal Animal Whisperer, DLC by DLC!

Rogue Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5) 

Ah, The Sims 4, the game where you can create a Sim version of yourself and then proceed to ruin their life in the most entertaining ways possible! I'm granting it a Rogue Rating of four out of five stolen garden gnomes because, let's be real, the DLCs are like my wallet's arch-nemesis, and the modding community is crazier than a bag of cats.

Now, let's talk about the DLCs. They're like the gourmet toppings on a Sim's existential pizza. From adding vampires and witches to throwing in a laundry day pack (because apparently, we want our Sims to suffer like we do), these expansions come at a price that could make a real-life Sim cry. But you know what they say, you can't put a price on giving your Sim the ability to become a mermaid with a knack for parenthood.

The graphics in Sims 4 are so vibrant that you'll swear your Sim's house is more put together than your own. And the character customization? It's like playing Barbie with unlimited wardrobe options, except your Barbie can also have an existential crisis and die from laughter while eating a salad.

But it's not just the official expansions that make this game a barrel of laughs; it's the fan-made mods! Want to turn your Sim into a llama-riding crime boss with a soft spot for stray cats? There's a mod for that! Heck, there's probably a mod that turns your Sim into a sentient toaster who's trying to become a world-renowned tap dancer.

Speaking of crime bosses and animal lovers, my character Zbra was a true Sims legend. He'd steal the neighbor's flamingos one day and adopt a horde of stray dogs the next. He's the kind of Sim who could throw a neighborhood party that ended with everyone stealing the furniture. Oh, Zbra, you beautiful, chaotic soul.

The Sims 4 community is like a Sims soap opera with drama, comedy, and way too many love triangles. You'll find players who are experts at building mansions that defy the laws of physics and Simmers who create storylines that rival Shakespearean tragedies. It's a place where creativity knows no bounds.

In conclusion, The Sims 4 is a hilarious and addictive life simulator where you can play puppeteer with your digital avatars. With DLCs that rival a luxury car's price tag and mods that can turn your Sims into just about anything, it's a game that keeps on giving. So, put on your llama-riding boots, adopt a herd of virtual animals, and dive headfirst into the absurdity that is The Sims 4!

You'll find this plenty of times on the net: 
Sims just installed  a routine update, and now all your saves are gone, together with any custom content you had installed.

You CANNOT play this game WITHOUT MODS or DLCs. The game is plain boring without them and the game is BROKEN without mods that fix them. 

I play this only with mods installed and only because there are no big Life Simulators like this out there. I'm a legacy family player and only buy DLCs on sale and are related to my type of gameplay(e.g. Growing Together, Parenthood). And I have a lot of mods that improve the gameplay because it DOESN'T WORK (i.e. the sims AI is stupid and brainless). 

If you don't want to install mods, I recommend waiting out the next life simulator games instead of playing this decade-old cash-grabby game. The DLCs are not worth the price they sell them for. If you really have to, BUY THEM ONLY ON SALE.

The Sims 4 Pros and Cons

Pros:

Infinite Creativity: The Sims is all about letting your imagination run wild. From designing unique characters with distinct personalities and appearances to building and customizing dream homes, the game provides an expansive canvas for creativity.

Endless Gameplay: The sheer number of expansion packs, stuff packs, and mods available for The Sims ensures that the game never gets stale. Whether you want to explore different careers, engage in romantic relationships, or simply enjoy the daily lives of your Sims, there's always something new to discover.

Accessible to All Ages: The Sims is a family-friendly game that appeals to a wide audience. Its easy-to-learn mechanics make it accessible to younger players, while its depth and complexity offer a rewarding experience for adults.

Engaging Social Dynamics: Watching your Sims interact with each other and the world around them is both humorous and engaging. The social dynamics and quirky behaviors of your virtual citizens can lead to surprising and entertaining situations.

Cons:

Expensive with Expansions: While the base game of The Sims 4 is free, the cost of expansion packs can add up quickly. Some players may find it challenging to keep up with all the additional content.

Limited Realism: The Sims is a life simulator with a lighthearted and often whimsical tone. While it captures many aspects of everyday life, it's not a true-to-life simulation, which may disappoint those seeking a more realistic experience.

Performance Issues: Depending on your computer's hardware, The Sims can occasionally suffer from performance issues, particularly when running the game with numerous expansion packs or mods.

In summary, The Sims 4 is a delightful and enduring life simulation game that offers an unparalleled level of creativity and entertainment. It's perfect for players of all ages who enjoy building, nurturing, and guiding virtual lives. The wealth of content and the community-driven modding scene ensure that there's always something new to explore in the world of The Sims.

I spend a lot of time in this game. But 95% of it is creating sims or households. Without mods, this game is as stale as a three week old burger. I previously had purchased this on console for $5 a while back, but recently got it on PC for the modding aspect. It was on sale last week. Why the hell did I think spending $4 extra dollars for the "deluxe version" was a good investment? ITS THE EXACT SAME AS THE REGULAR VERSION! I was expecting some extra content thrown in, but NOPE. Not a single thing.

Here's what you do in this game... you create a sim, you interact with other sims, and sit around and do nothing. Without spending all of your emergency savings on DLCs (of which there are 40. There's even a DLC for Laundry... LAUNDRY! Who would pay real money to do chores in a video game?!?) EA's greed is ridiculous. I haven't bought a single DLC, but I know how bad they are. The DLC'S are poop, to put it simply. The only DLC worth buying is the Cats and Dogs DLC. And only if that crap's on sale. You pay $40 for something that should be in the base game without question, first of all, and it adds 15 clothing items, 10 hair items, random furniture, and a bugged gameplay mechanic.

Listen to me when I tell you that you are better off downloading a 'placeholder' mod as an alternative to the DLC's. Of course, you can't get modded weather without that one DLC...

There is hardly any variety of furniture in the base game. Each object has maybe five variants (average), and you are forced to pick from the slim selection of color choices the game gives you. Want yellow counters? NOPE!

The one thing I must note is how good "Create a Sim" is. Apart from not being able to adjust height without a mod, you can change nearly every feature of a sim. Most of the time I spend is in Create A Sim, as I mentioned.

I'll make this simple by listing laughably vanilla features that this game makes you OVERPAY for (or doesn't even HAVE to begin with!):
-Weather
-Three extra occupations
-Laundry
-Dust
-Seasons
-Businesses
-Retirement
-Illnesses
-Transportation

As a result, you must buy DLCs for more experiences, but [b]‘The Sims 4’ seems to be a downgrade overall compared to ‘The Sims 3’[/b], and most importantly, please check the section of DLCs; this game has terribly many contents.

I love this game. I've logged so many hours building and playing the Sims 4. Currently I'm at over 4,000 hours. It's my favorite game I've ever played.

Luckily this game goes on sale regularly, but under ordinary circumstances the Sims 4 is outrageously priced for the DLC they provide. Unfortunately, the game is more fun with DLC than without. The price and some glitches are my top complaints. I have logged enough hours for it to be worth it to me, and the game is incredibly addictive. 

Would I buy it again? 100%. I love this game and have loved the Sims since the Sims 2. However, I would highly recommend adding it to your Steam Wishlist and waiting for the sales.  Also, buy it on PC through Steam. That way you can use cheats and mods. It will make your gameplay much better than buying on a console.

Disclaimer: This review may contain traces of exaggeration.

My first impression of this game was: what a bland and loveless game, stripped of every contet they had in previous sims games, just to sprinkle that lost content in thousands of dlcs, so you spend all your money on your liveless little digital puppets. "Just another dumb cashgrab" is what i thought "I won't fall for that", but i still played the basegame for a while to test it a bit more. It is free after all. And then I bought one little dlc. "It won't hurt" I thought "maybe this will make the game a little more entertaining". The time after that seems blurry. Turns out I underestimated its addiction factor. I spent hours, days, weeks and months sitting in front of my computer deciding the fate of my pathetic little creatures. I forgot to eat and sleep for days. My familiy and friends tried to help me, but I didn't even notice them. There was only sims. When I closed my eyes, all I could see were little green floating diamonds. It only ended after my power was shut down, because I coudn't pay the bills anymore, as I spent all my money on the countless dlcs.
I have never touched this game since. But I know that there will come a time, that this wicked game calls for me again and chain my mind to the endless void that is the sims 4.

PS: If you really want to play the game, just use Mods.

I've been a big fan of the sims franchise since I was a child, but I cannot advocate people to buy any of the DLC or give EA any attention at this point. The base game is free, but you can hardly do anything with it. It is meaningless without the packs, but even then the packs don't add much value to the game itself. You would be better off downloading mods and custom CC from amazing creators than spending up to 1k to get all the DLC and still have mediocre game play. The game is super buggy and every patch update makes it worse. EA doesn't want to address this yet still have the audacity to develop another DLC pack that could have been included in either the base game or in another game pack (seasons should have been base game!). This game is 10 years old and still feels like it is in production. What a joke.

I purchased this game at full price, $30 or so on steam. No money back or a nifty DLC that can replace the money lost. OH BUT YOU GET A $5 content pack with less content that what a modder can do in their spare time. You get a 6th of you paid for in return, none of the DLCs that have equal value to their full game(at the time) which by the way there is no reason to price a DLC at the same value as the game itself if it doesn't include the same amount of content as the base game. Imagine buying a full priced game, and then there is a DLC with a tenth of the amount of content with the same price tag that was included by default in previous titles. EA has went from a company I loved and held dear as a teen back in Sims 1 and 2 to now being an absolute garbage fire of a greedy company. obviously there would be more negative reviews but i'm sure those who bought the game very much gave up on it and left it to collect dust in their library. I would refund this if I could but obviously I can't,,, Smart play EA, but like the age old saying; "Fool me once" Next time EA throws out another sims or game with even worse quality of content and more heftier prices for what should have been base game to begin with; Watch to sales plummet. Nobody wins when you get too greedy.

The game itself is  bare-bones, although free at the point of writing this. I cannot recommend it by any means for as long as Sims 1, 2 and 3 exist; they stripped down the best elements of each game (esp. Sims 3), and then launched an "empty" game of sorts. This is only to spoon-feed you content at a pace for a ridiculous amount of money you'd need to pay if you ever wanted to have the FULL experience, and it stinks of that infamous mobile gaming, FOMO effect.

So, you might wonder. With about 260 hours of play, how come I don't recommend it? The answer is simple.

The fun and joy I'm having with this game is all credited to some 15.000 mods installed, and to those wonderful creative people who made them all possible. Cheers!

The Sims 4 is a great game. The possibilities in your sims world are endless. Each response, action, and decision is clearly well thought out and effective in your sims' life. Allowing you to build, start a career, throw parties, move houses, adopt pets, have children, and so much more, the Sims 4 is a super fun life simulator game that lets you completely have control over your Sims' decisions. It's a second life, where you can restart whenever you wish, and don't have to worry about problems getting in the way. Definitely recommend this game to all ages.

These phones everyone is carrying around everywhere. There's no place to put them things. I tried sliding it into my platform boots but it don't fit. I've tried sliding it into my hotpants, it don't fit. I even had my Granny sow me a pocket into my purple velvet cape and that's OK but when Mr. Sunshine comes beating down....- well I don't have to tell ya how that works out. No sir ree Bob. But I do see the necessity of them things though. Anyway, one afternoon I'm leaving the house with my thermos of bean soup when the agency calls. Now, mind you I'm already out the door by the cows when Pap comes runnin' with the phone, forgettin' its attached to the wall. He hits the end of that tether like a hound dog after a chicken and he goes flyin' back. Pap, he stumbles back and goes caterwauling ass over tea kettle into the basement and shatters his hips. Update 2023: Bugfest ... They made this game F2P ... makes sense ... it's full of bugs these days ... like:
- Plants randomly reverting to their seeded state
- Actions not finishing (like conversations or writing a book)
- Writing a book, progress reset to 0 sometimes
- finish a painting, only to get a white canvas that you can only destroy
- try reading a book to you child ... either your characters goes to the pool, waits, and then cancels the action, or just looks at the child and does nothing
- wash your hands after the toilet, sim goes to the sink that is the most far away
- go to build mode at night, move one item, resume play ... after hours you realize, that your sims have completely reset all their actions and are not sleeping anymore
- ... 


Original review:
Don't start a family in this game ... your character as well as your child run around randomly through the house when you tell them to do something.

- Put to bed? can't for some reason, even though you did it multiple times the last few days
- Teach to speak? No problem, i just go to the basement and wait for my kid to come after me
- Feed the Toddler? Sure put it in the seat, get food, and ... nothing ... wife picks up the kid and goes playing with her.
- Potty train after a bath? No problem, lets just stand around for 15 minutes before actually starting.
- Toddler takes food and goes to the BASEMENT!!! to eat??? WTF who programmed the AI for the kids??????
- Eating? Oh no child ... your mother takes you out of your chair in the middle of lunch ... who need food anyway ....

There is so much mixed emotions when it comes to ts4, it's great to play because it's a (now) free game but when it comes to the expansion packs, you might as well go fuck yourself and go to the bank and take out a loan, expansion packs along with the stuff packs and the kits I feel as if is a major contribution to the reason that there has been 9 year gap since the last sims game has been released when it is usually 5 years gap max. considering they make bank off of their $40 expansions, $20 off their game packs, $10 on their stuff packs and then $5 on their kits, they must see no reason to give us a 5th game. At this point were going to see gta 6 before ts5. 
I have alot of hope (almost too much hope) that one day maybe before my great great great grandchildren die that ea would add things to improve the game like

1.Open world
2.Better genetics
3.Sims growing more realistically (as opposed to the age up feature)
4. Height sliders (goes hand in hand with 3)
5.More activities for toddlers and infants
6.Preteens
7. Shopping centers, hair salons, tattoo shops
8. More living options (shelters? twin homes? living on the street?)

Along with the things i feel that would make the game better, heres what i think they should give us back from previous games

1.Sims biographies, gives more background and makes the story behind your sim much easier to tell
2. Cars
3. Playable pets
4. More traits
5. Burglars 
6. Create-a-style
7. More lots 
8. More story progression

There is quite a bit i am missing and I understand that there is mods for some of these issues but I just feel that it is such a bummer they have so many chances to add more dynamic to the game and decide they want to profit off of it instead. it's like nobody wants to work these days smh. In contrast to all the bad, there is so much that is great about the game, the horses, hearing aides, and the pride collection, overall smoother graphics, sim multitasking, adding your own events and holidays, infants, more animation and much more. 
They are such a cool things to have that i have not seem in previous games. 
One thing I also would really like to touch on is the bugs in ts4, starting with the millions of times that I play and I feel like my sim is starving to death within minutes of launching my game, the way the Sims ignore certain tasks no matter how many times you click on it, locking the computer and other sims still being able to use it, sims glitching into objects, and infants suddenly becoming 6ft tall.There are so many bugs i can probably touch up on considering a majority of their packs have mixed reviews mainly for buggung reasons but there is a final bug and may be the biggest bug/disappointment, High School Years. I love getting expelled every single day and having to cheat my way into getting back into high school, never being able to ship my sold thrifted outfits, Science fair bugs, prom happening too often, Just feels like everywhere I turn there's a bug (these have been complained about since HSY launch). The reason it's very disappointing is that it was a very hyped up pack by ea and its fallen short to everything it could've been, considering its very mixed/negative steam reviews.
If ea listened to its consumers Im pretty sure this game would be much better and have overwhelmingly positive reviews, it's a good game but it has SO much more potential that they aren't fixing. I know im not alone in how I feel because alot of what I have said is what I've seen other people say.
Since 2019 I have racked up approximately 4k hours of game play between steam and origin/ea, and this is where the mixed emotions come in. This game has many short comings and bugs but it's such a great game to kick back and relax to play. Will I complain about this game for years to come? Hell yeah! Will I still play it at the end of the day? Also hell yeah. I understand that my review is solely my opinion and no one has to agree with it, but this game will still be a recommend from me.

[h1]Rating: 2/10[/h1]

The core concept of the game is undeniably fun. There are so many ways to roleplay, create unique stories, and experiment with different scenarios. But let's be real here - this game's potential has been strangled by the relentless greed of its publishers.

I used to enjoy devising crazy experiments within the game, like trapping Sims inside boxes or creating chaotic situations just for laughs. It was all in good fun, and the game's mechanics allowed for endless creativity. However, my enjoyment has been overshadowed by the nauseatingly expensive DLCs that Electronic Arts shamelessly peddles.

The cost of these DLCs is absurd and sickening. Let's calculate:

Currently, there are 68 DLCs
14 Expansion Packs (39,99€ each) - 559,86€
12 Game Packs (19,99€ each) - 239,88€
19 Stuff Packs (9,99€ each) - 189,81€
23 Kits (4,99€ each) - 114,77€

TOTAL: 1 104,32€
(1 212.72 USD)

I'm not one to endorse piracy, but with the way EA is treating its players, The Sims 4 might just be the only game I'd consider doing it. It's a sad state of affairs when a once-beloved series has been tarnished to this extent by a company's insatiable appetite for profits. It's time for EA to wake up and realize that they're alienating their loyal player base with their outrageous pricing practices.

I have over 1k hours in The Sims 3 and Sims 2 respectfully.
Do not support this trash soulless company and their business practice that screws the consumer. 
Play the older titles, I promise you that you will get more fulfillment off a 15-20 year old game than this cash grab of a title. 
Games like this should be priced because they should be able to stand on their own as a great simulation title without the need to purchase additional content unless you are really enjoying the game. [h1]It is what it is. Mediocre[/h1]
[b]The game itself is pretty good.[/b] Don't get me wrong, I bet some people adore this version of The Sims. The problem is, it had so many great features brutally taken away (like the ability to freely change colors of furniture), that it's hard not to dislike it.

It really sucks that you gotta buy so many DLCs to get absolutely anything. In a way, I think they overdid it. There are SO. MANY. WORLDS., and the loading screen is the most annoying thing - Sims 3 didn't have that. Sure, certain users faced huge lag with the open world, but it was way better for me to have a [i]tiny lag[/i] every few hours, rather than looking at the loading screen for the frustrating 10 to 20 seconds anytime I want to move around. JUST LET ME PLAY MY GAME??? 

The sims do not listen to what I tell them to do, all of the actions I tell my sims to do get randomly cancelled, random dishes that do not get washed, bad pathfinding??? God.

Sims 3 >>> Sims 4. Now I am stuck with a kitchen that has 5 different tones of gray and 3 tones of black.

More or less the same Sims game we've been playing for 20 years, plus about a thousand dollars worth of DLC.

It's strange, then, that what REALLY bothers me is that the game needs to download & update Origin, plus a completely separate EA app to function. The game isn't good enough to deal with all that.

Also, unrelated: never watch content by Sims Youtubers. Deeply disturbing.

I have enjoyed The Sims for over 20 years now. I give up. I am done. Okay, ngl, I enjoy playing this game when it works. HOWEVER... It rarely works for more than a week or two in a row. They update and break it literally every 2-4 weeks. Sometimes it's not playable without corrupting your saves for months at a time. Since Steam prefaced the question, "Would you recommend this game...?" No, hell no, just download and play Sims 2 or 3. I mean, TS4 is visually beautiful, lots of wonderful worlds to explore and reside in and vacation to, but seriously do not buy this game. Just steal it. Not a time I start up to play goes by that I don't regret getting back into this franchise. The company has lost their freaking minds. Every time they release anything new, it breaks everything old. 

Forget about even avoiding mods, they're still gonna break your game about every few weeks, mods notwithstanding. Shoot there are two entire expansion packs that NEVER WORKED AT ALL and still have yet to be fixed. Even modders, who are the only devs that help players enjoy the game, haven't been able to fix them yet. Dining Out literally doesn't let your sims go to a restaurant, order a meal, and have it take under 12-14 hours [assuming they ever even get their orders]. I have chatted with people online who had sims literally starve to death at restaurants while waiting for food.

TL;DR Sims decided to remove most mean/mischief interactions because Toxic people don't exist in EA Land... When people at EA sleep under their desks for crunch...

No joke, I enjoyed Sims 4 for quite some time, even though I despise how much DLC this game has, it let you give personality to every sim you created, however they have severely limited mean/mischief interactions, which means the drama an antagonistic personality causes between sims is severely limited.

Snobby rich people are now neutered Elitists that no longer lord their income over others, and that Grumpy old man you designed to scream at kids for getting on his lawn is now Mr. Rogers, you can't have dorky slap fights, or cartoonish dustcloud fights.

I get that EA wants to live in a boring Utopia where everyone holds hands and sings Nursery Rhymes, but if you go outside and touch grass you'll find that this Utopia is detached from reality, that people want you to conform to their hivemind ideology or be destroyed, as opposed to dancing around with a purple dinosaur.

If it weren't for sex in dumpsters, I would say this is aimed at small children now, but since you CAN have sex in dumpsters, I'm kinda at a loss as to who this is supposed to be for anymore.

[h1] Pakoun's Unofficial Steam Reviews [/h1]
[b]Topic: The Sims™ 4 [/b]
When I purchased The Sims™ 4, It was $39.99 + tax. Since the base game of Sims™ 4 is "Free to Play" now, I believe this calls for an updated review. I made my original review on February 27, 2022, and I have a playtime average of 299.9 hours.

[b] Extra Information: "Pre-Free Players." [/b]
Steam users who purchased The Sims™ 4 before it became "Free to Play" have been offered little additional content for the money they spent on the base game (however, they did offer something even though EA were not obligated to.) They were offered a Desert Luxe Kit ($4.99 + tax), which was available as free until October 17, 2022. The base game also became "Free to Play" on this established date. (July 25, 2023.)

[b] The Sims™ 4: Base Game [/b]
The Sims™ 4 allows extensive customization and untold stories that you control. You play through your household of sims, build and decorate plots, and create personal goals. Electronic Arts (The company behind The Sims™ franchise) has offered routine updates and bug fixes. Furthermore, there have been several attempts to include cultural diversity. The Sims™ 4 requires a separate launcher to play.

[b] DLC: Expenses & More [/b]
The Sims™ 4 has a wide range of DLC: Expansion Packs (Large $39.99), Game Packs (Medium $19.99),  Stuff Packs (Small $9.99), and Kits (Mini $4.99). The Sims™ Community commonly debates if the DLC is worth it, citing that "it feels much like a cash grab," "microtransactions," and "the money isn't worth the content." DLC releases are frequent to the point that they are monthly, and members have complained about game-breaking bugs. 

[b] Game Modifications: Mod Friendly [/b]
The Sims™ 4 Mod Community isn't small, and they have created some fairly decent mods to spice up your experience! After each update, The Sims™ 4 will disable mods, and you will have to enable them each time. Some updates will break mods, so it may be a little while before your favorite mod creator creates a patch!

[b] Company Communication: Interactions [/b]
It has been noted that a fair portion of The Sims™ 4 community feels unheard by Electronic Arts Inc, so The Sims™ 4 doesn't have the best reputation for listening to community feedback. This can be supported by several Steam comments on the base game's posts.

[b]Veteran Player: Biased Review [/b]

[i] I have created this review based on my personal experience with the game and what I have seen from numerous places. This is simply to inform, not intentionally slander or be malicious. Do not take my words as fact - rather, take them as a caution and with a grain of salt.  [/i]

[i]Honestly, I don't recommend this game. Am I biased? Yes. I have played the Sims franchise for years. I grew up on it. As a veteran player, it is common that we expect a game that is supposed to be the successor for older games to provide more content and improvements. While the graphics have improved, The Sims™ 4 feels like it has earned the presence of a mobile game. [/i]

[i]What was included in the base game that enhanced the experience has been put behind a barrier paywall. DLC aside, The Sims™ 4 lacks several great features from its predecessors. The Open World has been replaced by "rabbit holes" and loading screens. There is no Create-a-style tool feature. Also, wasn't there a Sims Memory Book that was great for storytelling? The Sims™ 4 has damaged the legacy of The Sims™ franchise. [/i]

I would characterize this game as much more focused on preset objectives (fulfilling wishes and life objectives) than previous games, which you may or may not like.

The Sims 4 is an absolutely stunning installment in the long-standing Sims series of video games. From the highly detailed graphics to the flexibility of the creative tools players possess, The Sims 4 offers an astounding simulation of life that is unmatched by any other game in the industry.

Creating a Sim is one of the best features of The Sims 4. You can choose so many details ranging from physical traits to a starting personality template. It’s as simple or as complex as you want it to be and the possibilities are nearly endless. You can even design a dream-home for your Sim and furnish it with all kinds of modern amenities.

The career mode in The Sims 4 adds an entirely new layer of deepness to the game. It’s no longer just about sending your Sims to mundane jobs--you can now choose what path your Sim takes, from climbing the corporate ladder to owning a home business. It’s an incredibly fun and rewarding way to established goals in the game and the possibilities are seemingly endless.

The Sims 4 is an incredibly immersive and enjoyable game. It’s easy to get lost in the lives of your Sims, and there’s something for everyone whether you’re just starting out or a veteran of the series. It’s a perfect game for those who want a deep and rewarding experience while still having a lot of fun in the process. Highly recommended.

I mean, whatchu wanme tusei. In terms of content depth, TS3's still on a universally different level. TS4 also seems to be a game that's the most expensive to own. Thank (the higher plane of being) that EA reminded me to give this game a recommendation against buying it with its new horse DLC. 40 bucks. For horses.

I guess my review doesn't hold as much value if I didn't "grow up with the game", as I only played the hell out of The Sims 3 as a kid, but I can still draw a comparison. It just feels shallow. A game you can play for a while and then just... Drop. A dip in the pool.

You do the same everyday things as a Sim and that already seeps in that feeling of repetitiveness, and the fact that to go to a bar or other building you have to bring out the map and then do the loading stuff urks me off to just not do it. I personally found playing The Sims 4 after maybe 2 hours into the actual gameplay quite draining.

Alright. So, I initially sung nothing but praise for this game in my 230-ish hour review. Now, with 780+ hours in the game, I have a different opinion. Should you get this game now, whilst EA has *so graciously* made the base game free? Yes. Should you have bought this game, like I did? Absolutely not. The game itself is hardly enjoyable without mods and/or custom content. And DLC? Don't bother wasting your yearly salary on a couple packs. Go find an "alternative method". With the few packs I purchased (Vampires, Island Living, Realm of Magic, a few others), I found the content lacking, with the exception of one (Cats & Dogs, which was the only one which felt even remotely worth purchasing). My other "alternatively acquired" packs were only worth the space they took up on my hard drive because they weren't making any dent in my wallet.
So yeah. EA's money hungry. Sail the high seas, my friends.

Overall Review: 9/10 Free mods, runs smooth, adaptable to players wants / needs
Good things about the game:
- Runs great for me, even with 5k+ mods installed. I have an old laptop, where i have to connect 3-4 diff things to it for it to function.
- Base worlds are great, lots of adaptability and you can customize EVERY lot. 
- Good gender versatility (But there are mods available for additional things that aren't in the game)
Bad things:
- DLCS are REALLLYY expensive in my opinion. I haven't been able to get any yet at all.
- you have a lot of options, but limited in specific furniture needs / wants (THOUGH, ALMOST ALL CC MODS FOR SIMS, BUILDING, AND BUYING ARE FREE)
- For me? theres only so much i can do. i like building, i like making the sims. you CAN do adventures and things like that, but.. they didn't stick for me personally.

What can I possibly say about The Sims that hasn't already been said.... Well the game itself is sound if you like designing homes and building a world that you can then interact with you can put as much or as little time into it as you desire. It's geared towards people who like to design and add color and texture to their world. You can pretty much play God or yourself and embark on whatever type of life you desire. The surrounding community is really what makes this game I would encourage you to read some of the guides so that you know what CC is and things like Maxis match unlike a lot of games this was designed so it's pretty hard to get wrong, it was designed for lighthearted fun and someone with an eye for design in fashion architecture or human behavior will enjoy this game the most. There's many ways to spend your time in my opinion this beats the hell out of solitaire and the community that is supporting this game is the reason why it'll never truly become out of date or old

Yes.... the base game is free sort of it's kind of like free puppy if you've ever had a puppy They're definitely not free There's a lot of upkeep and growing it takes place even though The puppy becomes part of the family he turns out to be quite expensive which is offset by the love and friendship he provides. In the same way the sims make the bulk of their money through expansion packs They're looking to expand their user base which means more cool things in the gallery for everyone to enjoy you can stay mad about Having paid for the game when others are getting it for free but if they want to enjoying it Chances are They're going to pay for a bunch of expansion packs and become part of the very large community. At least that's what the business is Counting on so that they can continue to be profitable which is also good for the community Because it means they'll continue to support This game which over the years has grown to a full-blown community a lot of what makes a game good is the Developers what makes it great is the modding community that comes in and customizes it and unbelievable ways with a good developer or Developers They work with their mighty community to develop an even better game the people behind the sims 4 are not only trying to work with a developers but also the community which given the history says a lot for men it's easy and more affordable to just jump ship and start up a new company with all you've learned be thankful the sims 4 team has not done this.  And yes I actually did pay for my whole steam library including Sims 4. Some of the community Because it really is that large I don't work for the developers or anybody associated with the sims.

At the end of the day it's a game have fun if it stops being fun stop doing it for a while.

I loved life simulators and the Sims series has always been my most favourite. From the world building to the create-a-sim aspect, the Sims 4 has been the best life simulator ever created. I got it years before it was available for free, and regardless, the money spent was used and COMPLETELY worth it. I would buy this game again and again if I have it. I love it and will continue to recommend it to people I know.

I am a 54 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 18. My Son recently started Sims 4 and in less than a week, he had already played for over 25 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on where you were supposed to go. I asked my Son for help and he joined my coop. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is great! However, I only play it modded. The base Sims is somewhat boring after a little while, and It looks sorta lame. It's got bad lighting and it's near impossible to make your Sims cute or attractive. The randomize button seems to only be capable of producing hell spawns. I recommend searching online Sims 4 CC (Custom Content). There are tons of modifiers like different clothes, makeup, body types, skins and textures and way more. If you end up downloading a lot like I have (around the 2,000 mods mark) you should look into finding a mod manager. Make sure to turn on Allow Custom Content, and Allow Scripts in the Sims 4 settings. Turning on scripts will allow some of your game-play mods to work. If you download any .script files you'll need to have it enabled. Modding is extremely easy and plenty stable for this game!! Looking up a simple tutorial on YouTube will tell you everything you need to know. But yeah, I would never play un-modded sims.. Very boring and low quality in my opinion, but it makes a great base of a game. 

Also the Sims 4 Packs or the DLC is extremely expensive, and it's very gross of EA to allow this to happen. :<

I think I play this game far too much, though it's really only enjoyable if you download CC and buy packs, which is upsetting because of the sheer amount each pack costs.

Edit: Now that the Sims is free to play, I'd say it's definitely worth getting. Like I said previously, downloading CC is the way to go. It can enhance your game SO much more than some packs would. It's unfortunate that some key features of standard simulation games are locked behind a pack paywall. A few mods I recommend are MCC Command Center (allows you to unlock and use many cheats), UI Cheats, and More Columns in CAS (especially if you download a bunch of CC like I do). 

If you're interested in getting a pack, for starters, BUY THEM WHEN THEY'RE ON SALE. The one pack I absolutely recommend is Seasons. Seasons is absolutely crucial to the game because it does exactly as it sounds: adds seasons to the game. Not only that, but it also adds events to the calendar, such as Halloween or Christmas.

I love this game. Though it's pretty much just a virtual dollhouse, there's so much you can do to keep it interesting. You can customise your Sim's houses, outfits, and there's unique, interactive NPCs in every non-vacant lot.

Though, there is a few issues with this game. The packs are WAY overpriced. Why do the packs cost more than the game? And I feel like certain packs, like Seasons, should just be included regardless, due to the fact The Sims 4 is a life simulator, and... well: weather is a very big and necessary part of life.

Another issue is your Sims itself. Especially with the new infant update. I stack a bunch of actions in my Sim's taskbar to take care of the dishes, change the baby's diaper, wake up the dog, empty the trash can, take a shower... et cetra. The Sim cancels it ALL and stands there staring off into the abyss. That is really frustrating.

I'm being absolutely honest with how the game had progressed over the years. It always houses itself to be one of the simulation games with great potential but it's just handicapped by the unbearable price of your kidney for all the instalments just to make it repayable. So in summary find alternatives on downloading contents to at least making it resemble similar to the walkthroughs you see the youtubers playing through :)

Mods like extreme violence, wicked whims (download at your own risk itll scare you) and other cute little mods do add a layer of fun for basegame baddies and furniture and cas cc (custom content) is always a nice alternative to the stuff you find in packs and dlcs, but unless you use a sketchy unlocker online to get some for free, your gonna be dropping lots of money for basic necessities like weather, going to school, starting a business or even unlocking a new world.

The sims 4 at its core has 3 worlds your allowed to explore with your sim(s) if you chose to play dlc free. Willow creek, basically your bread and butter world that youll spend a lot of time in, it has a few neighborhoods and public lots (parks etc) but there nothing much to interact with, and this goes for a ton of the worlds in the sims, dlc or not, the most youll get out of a world is a street festival or a highschool. 

The next basegame world is oasis springs, it essentially has the exact same content as willow creek with sand and a different layout.

The last basgame world you get is newcrest, a completely baron world with 15 blank lots to allow you to get creative and build your own world, the only issue is 90% of the tools you'll need to build your very own sims 4 world (businesses, school, holidays) is locked behind many paywalls, see the issue?
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Moving on from worlds, and i promise this wont turn into me reviewing all the packs in one long ass review, but let me list off a few things that will be locked for you unless you choose to spend some money.

- Cats and Dogs (cats and dogs pack)
- owning a farm (cottage living pack)
- owning a business (get to work pack)
- following a sim to work (get to work pack)
- following a sim to highschool (even then, the highschool is easily the most boring highschool youll ever see, and it cannot be customized) (highschool years pack)
- vampires, mermaids, aliens, skeletons, werewolfs (vampires, island living, get to work, jungle adventure, werewolfs respectively, however all of these except for skeletons are very interactive and i would honestly say are worth it)
- apartments (city living pack)
- weather, yes, you have to pay a pretty ass penny to watch it rain in the sims 4, its a scam and anyone telling you it isn't is batshit insane. (seasons pack)
- holidays (seasons pack)
- going to university (discover university pack)
- social media (highschool years pack)
-  spas (spa day pack)
- sleepovers (highschool years pack)
and much much more.

all of these necessities that you think would be basic for a life sim are locked behind $20 dollar plus paywalls with bare minimum content to customize your sim and their houses, and even then, things like the cats and dogs packs are split into different dlcs, making you buy the basics first and the fancier basics afterwards.

Not to mention half of the DLCs have become completely worthless due to EA recycling past content with a fresh coat of paint and fancier functions into other packs for a higher price.
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Now for the good

EA makes modding this game VERY easy, theres a folder called mods in the game files that you just drag and drop things into, these mods can be found on pinterest, youtube, tiktok and many dedicated sites. they provide things ranging from new clothes and furniture to cheats and brand new gameplay functions, and 99% of them will be free, the ones that aren't are breaking EA's terms of service, which is ironic. 

Not to mention, if diversity is something your looking for in a game, this is it. sims are can be customized completley, from the way they talk and walk to the way they look, the pronouns they go by, if they can give birth or not, their attractions, mannerisms, physical frame, likes and dislikes and much much more.

Its also a very casual and non challenging game, which can be a plus or minus based on what you personally prefer.

-----------------------------------------------------

TLDR = you will be charged for many basic tools to make the game fun and sims 4 as a base game is baron at best, but its also a customizable experience and easy to mod and play

While the user interface in Sims 4 may be superior due to its modern, clean design and smoother functionality, the core gameplay does not measure up to that of Sims 3. The lack of certain depth and complexity found in Sims 3, along with the removal or simplification of many gameplay aspects, makes the experience in Sims 4 somewhat less satisfying for long-time fans of the series. This has resulted in a feeling that, despite the upgraded UI, the essence of what made the Sims franchise unique and engaging has been diluted in Sims 4.

[b]Title: Sims 4: A Captivating Virtual Life, but with its Quirks[/b]

Stars: ⭐⭐⭐☆☆ (3/5)

Sims 4, oh how you've stolen countless hours of my life! This virtual life simulation game has consumed me like no other. I've spent more time creating and customizing my Sim's outfits than I have on my own wardrobe. The attention to detail is astounding, from the intricacies of home design to the vast array of career paths and aspirations.

But let's not forget the delightful chaos that ensues. It's both amusing and frustrating how my Sims can't seem to handle even the simplest tasks without my intervention. I've watched in amusement as they set the kitchen on fire while attempting to make a grilled cheese sandwich, or stand idly by as they get lost in the house they've lived in for years.

All in all, Sims 4 is a captivating and addictive virtual experience that lets me unleash my creativity and indulge in the absurdity of virtual life. Just be prepared to lose track of time and occasionally question your priorities. While it has its quirks, it's a solid choice for fans of life simulation games.

Do NOT get this you get sucked in and waste all your money cause you get addicted to having silly little lesbians in their silly little house that is boring because you have nothing because you don't have any money to get any of the expansion packs. do not listen to the people who say that the base game is fun this was a waste of money. In order to have fun you have to spend hours of your time looking for mods that fit all of your sim's aesthetics and then find a whole bunch of future  mods that will add somewhat tasteful furniture because the base game furniture SUCKS BOOTY BUTT. Or you have to sell your soul and buy every single expansion pack because nobody will ever have fun with just the base game. You can't even start a family, you have to spend another 20 bucks to do that. the base game might be free now but THE GAME IS NOT FREE you will have a bad time if you have no expansion packs and don't want to sell your soul and spend half of your fucking life downloading mods and DESTROYING you storage. and do not get me started on some of the mods this game has to offer because OH BOY. There is this mod, wicked whims, this mod was the worst decision i have ever made. i thought " oh, it won't be that bad!" WRONG. OH MAN this mod was NASTY. the worst possible things happen and one who downloads that mod is a freak and should feel ASHAMED. Now, not only do you have to sell your soul and spend all your money, but you have to spend HOURS making not only a sim that you are happy with, but an ENTIRE HOUSE that you are pleased with. Now, not only are the building controls confusing as hell but they are also very tedious. If you want to be able to place clutter freely you not only have to manually bring up the thing you want to put on the table, but you have to estimate where all the clutter will be on the table IN MID AIR. Now I'm not sure how hard it is to be able to let players place clutter freely on tables but it can't be that hard. so if you estimate where the clutter will be on the table wrong, you now have to move every. single. piece of clutter you had positions and change it so it will actually look nice on the table, you will have to do this like 5 or 6 times. I can't really complain about any of the other building features because I had enough when trying to freely place clutter on tables. Anyways, i love and hate this game at the same time the love only comes from me getting sucked into it and seeing how much fun people have when they spend the time and money to actually have fun, so please if you are on the fence about getting into this game, do yourself a favor and DON'T. You will regret it and your wallet, your free time, and your sleep schedule will hate you for it. But I do like having silly little lesbians. They make me happy!!

Sims is a fantastic game that allows endless creativity, interactive storytelling, and honestly a lot of things to do! A recent update to the Sims added a "preferences" feature. Its the addition to the game that allows sims to be straight (yawn) but also decides what kind of food or music they like, and gives them moodlets based on what they eat or listen to.

Which brings me to my fallout-style bunker experiment, in which I put the sims on full autonomy in the game settings, and lock them all in a bunker with everything they need to live. I don't directly control the Sims, but I do indirectly mess with their environment if I think they're too comfortable.

The bunker had a jukebox in the common area, central to all the living quarters. Someone turned on the jukebox, and set it to Christmas music. The bored sims all come out and start dancing to the Christmas music.

Then I get a pop-up message: "So'n'so is not really feeling the tunes she is listening to. Is it safe to say she *dislikes* Christmas Music?"

Fastest I have ever hit yes on a pop-up message.

So here she is, dancing to the music because the is bored, and continually getting more and more ANGRY at the music because its just Jingle Bells on repeat. She gets so angry that she goes to the bathroom to scream in the mirror for a few minutes.... Then goes back out to the common area to keep dancing! The cycle continued for some time: dance, get angry, scream, get bored, dance....

And then the message started popping up for other people, so eventually I had a whole group of miserable people angerly dancing to Jingle Bells, and it occurred to *none* of them to change the music because... They were too polite? Didn't want to change it if someone put it on? Were these Canadian bunker-inhabitants?

I expected them all to die in a kitchen fire like they did when I tried this in Sims 3, but this happening was so much better than I could have dreamed. 11/10.

I'm playing this game for 2 reasons only, because I paid for it and because I like to build houses and decorate them with nothing but custom fan made content. Otherwise I'd delete it from my library and never play it again. Why? Because it ruins custom content every time the game updates, which is frequently, and unless the author of the custom content fixes their mod, it won't work. (Which is not the authors fault, it's EA's fault for not letting us play the game with  no opt out of updates) I have 17,520 mods I use, and I'm not going to try to find every authors fix. This wouldn't be an issue if you didn't have to have the EA app, but you do, so even if you go in offline mode on the EA app when you start the game, if the EA app kicks in before you can take it offline, your game updates and your mods are ruined. Also, I just noticed the last few days that even Steam won't let me go in offline mode with this game. It won't let me play until I am online in Steam and online in the EA app. I detest both companies because of this. I don't recommend this game for people who  want to relax and build with beautiful mods. If  you just want to play a crappy game with ugly, plasticky looking graphics and textures, then go for it.

The only reason I recommend it because the game is really worth it to play if things goes well... I mean the base game is available for free and compare the state of this game way back 2014. It have a lot of content to keep you from playing but I do not assure the longevity of the gameplay. Especially when you do live mode. The Sims 4 brought innovative and complex build/buy mode yet the live mode aspect of the game is still lacking even you have packs included... For me this is the reason why you make go hungry for buying a pack to expand the longevity of your gameplay... To be honest some of the packs are pretty worth it and I could play those for hours... Then you burn out and drop the game for god knows how long and play it again, then repeat. In regards of buying a packs DO NOT BUY THEM FULL PRICE (unless you really want to) Im telling you the packs are worth half the price EA just love to over charge it only for a content that is worth from what its sale price... Lastly Mods and CC adds more flavor and gameplay to it but beware because every update of the game catastrophe happens and sorting these are pretty challenging. In conclusion Sims 4 is good for drop and play (well for me) style where it could keep you playing for several hours then you burn out and stop and pick up the game whenever you feel like it. The base game is good but once you feel like you have play the entirety of it you'll gonna crave for buying a pack...!

One of the best Life Simulator games out there, if not the best. 
I've spent quite a long time on this game, and I can confidently say, it's worth it.
I mostly use the Sims for the house building, the architecture and such. If you're into family simulation, this is the game for you!
The base game already has quite a lot, and I bought it ages before it became free. 
My pack recommendations are the Cats and Dogs pack, and the Farm pack, since these implement some really awesome features into your game. 
There's even a whole community dedicated to CC (Custom Content) and things, that really add to it.
Recently, EA has added pronouns, and gender features that make the game inclusive and I quite enjoy that. Not to mention the babies! Oh my gosh, finally! Silly little gremlin creatures but they're so worth it!
So get the Sims 4, seriously. You'll love it!

This is a great game for people who really enjoy simulations and gaming that involves creating, experimenting and simulating real-life. 

I bought this game originally in maybe 2013, on my Xbox for myself, even before I had purchased the mobile Sims 3 app as well. Ever since I first bought it, I have been non-stop playing, purchasing the new packs and playing each and every scenario that was realised in the game, every challenge posted on the internet, (I have played MANY different versions of the generations challenge too) I love this game because of its consistent updates and new features you can implement. 

This game is about creating Sims, fictional people in the game that you play as, you can make families, single person household, celebrities, mermaids, vampires and werewolves now. There are endless creative possibilities in this game, along with creating sims you can also build your dream homes and places like spas, gyms, retail stores and restaurants that will provide a whole new aspect to the game. It's almost like creating your own little town, but enabling you to focus on a household at a time. You can make your sims become famous painters, incredible astronauts, evil criminals, amazing parents, intense business people and crazy scientists. The possibilities never stop. 

I highly recommend this game, its so fun and its so relaxing and is a great escape from reality, allowing you to play and be anything you want your sims to be with almost real life accuracy to the problems faced in reality.

The Sims 4 is a fun game to get sucked into and waste an afternoon away with. The most fun is giving your sims very different 'aspirations' (main quests) so there are many different areas of the game and the map to explore. Then of course they all need jobs aligned with those aspirations, and you need to grow their skill sets and friendships etc etc. 

Because of all the small subtasks you quickly forget how long you've been playing and everything about your sim and the game is highly customizable. I used to play it mostly to build different styles of houses and have fun decorating the interior. But you can also play 'scenarios' where you start with a pre-made household which has been through some tough times and you need to get them back on track. Very fun. I just wish it added in more pre-made households to fill the neighborhood with when you start the game. It's pretty empty otherwise and building that up and giving them all houses takes too much time. 

The biggest down side is the build -mode has had a horrible new lay out which makes it so hard to find stuff. And the new in-game music is bad. But you can just turn that off.
